title: Neal v. Pearson
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Thomas Oâ€™Neal, Rhudean Spencer, Aquilla Oâ€™Neal, Jeral H. Smith, Finley Oâ€™Neal, Jr., Virgil D.H. Oâ€™Neal, Diane P. Kennedy, Linda Butler, Walter Oâ€™Neal, Evelyn Oâ€™Neal, George Oâ€™Neal, Jr., Raye Boyd, Gaye Harper, Cynthia Riley, Santana Jarboe, Cassandra Horton, and Crystal Mims, Respondents/Appellants,
				v.
				Unita Pearson, Hattie Lee Black, Ruby Young, Patrick Oâ€™Neal, and (as defendants whose names are unknown) any child or children and any heirs at law or distributees or devisees of the above named persons if they or any of them be dead, and any and all persons entitled to claim by, through or under them, or any of them; also any and all other persons unknown claiming any right, title, estate, interest in or lien upon the real estate described in the complaint herein, all such unknown adults who are sui juris being as a class designated as John Doe and all such persons who are under the age of eighteen (18) years, incompetent, incarcerated, in the military service or suffering under some other legal disability being as a class designated as Richard Roe, Appellants/Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal from Fairfield County
Â Kenneth G. Goode, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-340
Heard February 6, 2007 â€“ Filed July 6, 2007Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				D. Reece Williams, III, and Louis H. Lang, both of Columbia, for Appellants/Respondents.
				Raymon E. Lark, Jr., and E. Crosby Lewis, both of Columbia, for Respondents/Appellants.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Certain intestate heirs of Walter Wise Oâ€™Neal (collectively â€œthe Oâ€™Nealsâ€) challenged a 1961 deed granting 100 acres of property to Unita Pearson, alleging the deed was forged.Â  The case was first submitted to a jury, which answered the questions set forth in a special verdict form.Â  The trial court then considered the equitable issues and upheld the deed.Â  Pearson and the Oâ€™Neals both appeal.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Before his death, Walter Wise Oâ€™Neal (Father) owned over two hundred acres of land in Fairfield County.Â  He had nine children.Â  He and some of his children lived on the land in a home the family called the â€œBig House.â€Â  Sometime after his wifeâ€™s death, he moved in with his daughter, Unita Pearson.Â  Pearson filled the role of matriarch in the family.Â 
 
Beginning in 1961, Father deeded one-acre tracts to his children.Â  Most of the children built houses on the tracts.Â  Also in 1961, Father allegedly conveyed 100 acres of his land to Pearson.Â  The deed appears to be properly witnessed and notarized.Â  Pearson testified Father gave her the executed deed, but she did not see him sign it.Â  According to Pearson, Father told her to take the deed and record it.Â  She placed the unrecorded deed in a trunk in her home.Â  She did not record the deed until August 9, 1969. 
 
In 1964, Father had a stroke.Â  Pearson subsequently became Fatherâ€™s primary caregiver; while the other children often brought him food and spent time with him.Â  Father died intestate in 1968.Â 
 
Pearson handled the family affairs after Father died.Â  She paid all of the property taxes and leased hunting rights to the land.Â  However, testimony also indicates the other children would give her money to help pay the property taxes when the revenue from leasing hunting rights did not cover the tax bill.Â  
 
In the fall of 1999, Leon Thompson, a surveyor, found the deed in the Fairfield County courthouse and informed George Oâ€™Neal, another of Fatherâ€™s children, of the deedâ€™s existence.Â  George and his son went to an attorney, who recommended hiring a handwriting expert.Â  As a result, they hired Marvin H. Dawson, Jr. to examine the deed.Â  Dawson issued a report, opining the signature on the deed was not Fatherâ€™s and Pearson could not be eliminated as the person who signed Fatherâ€™s name.Â  After receiving more samples, he contended Pearson signed Fatherâ€™s name on the deed.[1]Â  
 
In early 2001, Pearson sold timber from the 100 acre tract for $222,203.00.Â  The Oâ€™Neals filed the present action on April 19, 2001.Â  They later obtained a temporary injunction, restraining Pearson from using any of the remaining proceeds of the timber sale.Â 
 
The Oâ€™Neals amended their complaint twice.Â  The second amended complaint alleged Father did not sign the deed and that Pearson forged his signature.Â  As a result, the Oâ€™Neals sought to set aside the deed, damages for fraud, an accounting of all funds generated from Pearsonâ€™s use of the 100-acre tract, a constructive trust over the remaining funds, a judicial partition of the 100-acre tract, and a partition of all of the land owned by Father at his death.Â  The Oâ€™Neals and Pearson later stipulated to the partition of the remaining land.Â 
 
Pearsonâ€™s answer to the Second Amended Complaint denied the forgery allegation and set up affirmative defenses of the statute of limitations, laches, estoppel, waiver, adverse possession, and presumption of a grant.Â  On March 17, 2004, Pearson was found to suffer from the early stages of Alzheimerâ€™s disease.Â  Consequently, she was unable to assist with her defense and her son was appointed as her guardian ad litem.Â  
 
The legal and equitable issues were bifurcated; Pearson and the Oâ€™Neals first tried the issues of forgery and fraud before a jury.Â  The Oâ€™Neals explained they would prove Father did not sign the deed and Pearson forged the deed.Â  Several family members testified, as did Dawson.Â  In addition, Pearsonâ€™s deposition testimony was read into the record.Â 
 
After all the evidence was presented, the Oâ€™Neals and Pearson agreed to a jury verdict form, which reads, in pertinent part:
 

	1. Did Walter Wise Oâ€™Neal sign the deed to the 100 acres in question?
	___ Yes. If you answer yes, stop.
	___ No. If you answer no, go to question 2.
	2. Did Defendant Unita Pearson commit forgery by signing the deed to the 100 acres in question?
	___ Yes. If you answer yes, go to question 3.
	___ No. If you answer no, stop.
	3. Did Defendant Unita Pearson commit fraud against Plaintiffs?
	___ Yes. If you answer yes, go to question 4.
	___ No. If you answer no, go to question 5.
	4. If you answered yes to either question 2, question 3, 
	or questions 2 and 3, then please answer the following question: what is the total amount of 
	actual damages from Defendant Unita Pearson to which Plaintiffs are entitled as a result of their
	forgery, fraud, or forgery and fraud claims?
	. . . .

In its jury instructions, the trial court explained the jury would decide the issues of fraud and forgery.Â  The jury deliberated and returned a verdict, checking â€œNoâ€ on question 1 and â€œNoâ€ on question 2 of the verdict form.Â  As instructed, the jury stopped after finding Pearson did not forge the deed by signing it.Â 
 
Pearson moved for judgment not withstanding the verdict (JNOV), arguing the trial court should grant her a judgment based on adverse possession or the presumption of a grant.Â  After the Oâ€™Neals filed a return, the trial judge held a hearing and subsequently entered an order denying the motion and holding the jury â€œeffectively found that there was sufficient evidence indicating [Pearson] had not established . . . its affirmative defenses . . . .â€Â  Additionally, the trial judge held â€œthe legal issues . . . are now concluded . . . . The equitable defenses will remain active pending resolution of the equitable claims and defenses in this case.â€Â  Pearson filed a notice of appeal from that order.Â  The appeal was held in abeyance while the equitable issues were considered by the trial judge.Â 
 
After a hearing on the equitable issues, the trial judge entered an order upholding the deed, finding the jury had concluded no forgery had taken place.Â  The judge also held the doctrine of laches barred the Oâ€™Nealsâ€™ action.Â  The court subsequently denied the Oâ€™Nealsâ€™ motion to alter or amend the judgment.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal, the Oâ€™Neals argue the trial court erred in denying their claims of setting aside a deed, an accounting, a constructive trust, and partition.Â  These are all equitable actions.Â  See Â Bullard v. Crawley, 294 S.C. 276, 278, 363 S.E.2d 897, 898 (1987) (stating action to set aside a deed is in equity); Laughon v. Oâ€™Braitis, 360 S.C. 520, 524, 602 S.E.2d 108, 110 (Ct. App. 2004) (stating actions seeking an accounting and partition are equitable);Â  Doe v. Roe, 323 S.C. 445, 448, 475 S.E.2d 783, 784 (Ct. App. 1996) stating action to declare a constructive trust is in equity).Â  In an equitable action, the appellate court may find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Townes Assocs. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â  â€œ[W]hen issues common to both legal and equitable claims are to be tried in a single proceeding, legal issues are to be determined first, and the findings of the jury are binding on the sitting judge, as trier of the equitable claims.â€Â  Johnson v. South Carolina Nat. Bank, 292 S.C. 51, 55, 354 S.E.2d 895, 897 (1987).Â  
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
The Oâ€™Neals argue the trial judge erred in interpreting the juryâ€™s verdict and applying it to preclude equitable relief.Â  Specifically, the Oâ€™Neals contend the juryâ€™s finding that Father did not sign the deed implies the deed was forged and, therefore, void.Â  We disagree.[2]
Initially, we hold the Oâ€™Neals waived this argument by agreeing to submit the issue of forgery to the jury and agreeing to the jury form.Â  When a verdict is objectionable as to form, the party who desires to complain should call that fact to the courtâ€™s attention when the verdict is published. Â If the party fails to do so, the right to complain is waived.Â  Bensch v. Davidson, 354 S.C. 173, 179, 580 S.E.2d 128, 131 (2003).
In this case, the trial judge submitted the issue of forgery to the jury.Â  The Oâ€™Neals did not object to this portion of the jury charge.Â  Further, the verdict form, to which the Oâ€™Neals agreed, informed the jury to stop if it found Pearson did not forge the deed.Â  Under the terms of the verdict form, only if the jury answered â€œYesâ€ to the question of whether Pearson forged the deed could the jury make a finding of forgery.Â  Accordingly, the Oâ€™Neals waived their right to establish forgery by some other theory.

Furthermore, the Oâ€™Neals are incorrect in their proposition that they proved forgery by showing Father did not sign the deed.Â  Forgery is defined as: â€œThe false making or the material altering of a document with the intent to defraud.Â  A signature of a person that is made without the personâ€™s consent and without the person otherwise authorizing it.â€ Â Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary (6th ed. 1990).Â  When a deed is valid and regular on its face, it is presumed to be valid in all respects. Â Davis v. Monteith, 289 S.C. 176, 182, 345 S.E.2d 724, 727 (1986). Â â€œWhere a grantorâ€™s signature is placed on the instrument by the hand of another, the grantor presumptively adopts this signature as his or her own absent clear and convincing evidence to the contrary.â€Â  26A C.J.S. Deeds Â§385 (2001); see also Thompson v. Shell Western E & P Inc., 607 So.2d 37, 40 (Miss. 1992) (expressing the same rule); Guthrie v. Gaskins, 155 S.E. 185, 187 (Ga. 1930) (holding a presumption that a grantor authorized the signing of a deed arises when the deed is properly witnessed and acknowledged).
The Oâ€™Neals rely on two South Carolina cases to support their proposition that they only needed to prove Father did not sign the deed: Barrett v. Miller, 283 S.C. 262, 321 S.E.2d 198 (Ct. App. 1984) and Kirven v. Lawrence, 244 S.C. 572, 137 S.E.2d 764 (1964).Â  We find their reliance on these cases misplaced.
In Barrett v. Miller, Barrett sued a church to set aside a deed to the church of a one-acre tract of land on the grounds that the deed was a forgery. Â The parties agreed to submit the issue of whether Barrett signed the deed to a jury.Â  In addition, the parties agreed that, if the jury found for Barrett, the issue of further relief would be decided by the judge.Â  
 
The jury found for Barrett, and the judge referred the remaining issues to a master.Â  The master found Barrett had been unjustly enriched because the church constructed a building on the premises.Â  This court reversed the masterâ€™s finding with respect to damages, holding the master erred in awarding damages greater than the increased value of the property as a result of the churchâ€™s construction.Â  Further, this court found equitable relief was improper because the church could use statutory law allowing a party to recover for good faith improvements made to real property which is later adjudicated to belong to another party.Â  Barrett, at 264, 321 S.E.2d at 199.Â  Frankly, we fail to see any possible application of Barrett to the facts of this case. 

In Kirven v. Lawrence, the heirs of a grantor sued the heirs of a grantee to set aside a conveyance.Â  The parties submitted the question of whether the grantor lacked the sufficient mental capacity to execute the deed to the jury.Â  The jury found for the heirs of the grantor.Â  After the supreme court reinstated the verdict, which had been set aside by the master, the heirs of the grantee sought to amend their answer to allege several affirmative defenses, including restoration of the mortgage status existing at the time of the transfer of the deed. 
 
Our Supreme Court affirmed the trial judgeâ€™s decision to allow the amendment.Â  In so holding, the court explained the doctrine of restoration: â€œRestoration of the status quo is required of one seeking judicial cancellation of an instrument. . . .â€Â  Kirven, 244 S.C. at 579, 137 S.E.2d at 767 (citations and internal quotations omitted).Â  The Oâ€™Neals point to this language to support their position.Â  Again, we see no application of Kirven to the present case.Â  
 
No where in either of those cases did the court make any holding that could be interpreted to mean that the challengers to a deed need only prove that the grantor did not sign the deed himself.Â  The Oâ€™Neals are mistaken in their assertion that by finding Father did not sign the deed, the jury found that they had proved that the deed was forged.Â  The Oâ€™Neals are also mistaken in their contention that they should prevail because Pearson did not allege that the deed was signed by someone else with Fatherâ€™s authorization.Â  Pearson did not bear the burden of proof on that issue.Â  As the challengers to the deed, the Oâ€™Neals had the burden of proving that the deed was forged.Â  This burden included not only proving that Father did not sign the deed, but also proving by clear and convincing evidence that it was signed by someone else without Fatherâ€™s authorization.Â  We find the trial judge correctly held the Oâ€™Neals failed to carry their burden to prove that the deed was a forgery.Â  Thus, we hold the trial judge did not err in denying their claims for equitable relief including setting aside the deed.Â  
 
CONCLUSION
We hold the Oâ€™Neals waived their right to challenge the trial judgeâ€™s interpretation and application of the juryâ€™s verdict.Â  Alternatively, we reject the Oâ€™Nealsâ€™ contention they proved forgery by showing Father did not sign the deed.Â  A party seeking to invalidate a deed for an alleged forgery bears the burden of proving, by clear and convincing evidence, the grantorâ€™s signature is unauthorized.Â  Accordingly, the trial judgeâ€™s decision is
AFFIRMED.[3]
HUFF, BEATTY, and WILLIAMS, JJ. concur.Â  


[1] The Oâ€™Neals also provided Dawson with a copy of deed dated June 10, 1964 granting Thomas and Louise Oâ€™Neal one acre, which was witnessed by the same individuals as the Pearson deed.Â  The Oâ€™Neals contended Pearson had signed that deed also.Â  Dawson agreed with that contention.Â  The Oâ€™Neals however did not seek to have that deed voided.Â  
 
[2] Pearson asserts this court lacks jurisdiction because the Oâ€™Neals failed to appeal from the juryâ€™s verdict.Â  The Oâ€™Neals, however, are not directly attacking the juryâ€™s verdict on appeal.Â  Instead, they charge error in the trial judgeâ€™s interpretation and application of the verdict and the trial judgeâ€™s decision that laches bars equitable relief.Â  The alleged errors occurred, if at all, within the trial judgeâ€™s order denying equitable relief.Â  The Oâ€™Neals timely appealed from the orders denying their equitable claims.Â  Accordingly, we find this court has jurisdiction to consider the Oâ€™Nealsâ€™ appeal.Â  
 
[3]As we find the trial court did not err in refusing to set aside the deed because the Oâ€™Neals failed to carry their burden of proving the deed was a forgery, we need not address Pearson and the Oâ€™Nealsâ€™ remaining arguments.Â  See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (ruling appellate court need not review remaining issues when disposition of prior issues are dispositive).Â

title: BPD Diversified v. Benchmark Capital Investment
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				BPD Diversified, Inc., d/b/a Bank Planning and Design, Respondent,
				v.
				Benchmark Capital Investment, LLC, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Charles B. Simmons, Jr., Master-In-Equity
Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2007-UP-347
Submitted June 1, 2007 â€“ Filed July 6, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Randall Scott Hiller, of Greenville, for Appellant.
				Theodore Von Keller, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  BPD Diversified, Inc., d/b/a Bank Planning and Design (â€œBPDâ€), brought this action for foreclosure of a mechanicâ€™s lien and breach of contract against Benchmark Capital Investment, LLC (â€œBenchmarkâ€). Â Benchmark failed to answer the complaint and went into default.Â  BPD obtained separate judgments in its favor on each of the claims.Â  Benchmark appeals, arguing the master erred in denying its motion to be relieved from the default judgment and in awarding an excessive amount of attorneyâ€™s fees to BPD.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On March 17, 2005, BPD signed an Architectural and Construction Agreement to design, remodel, furnish, and equip a bank branch facility owned by Benchmark in Greenville, South Carolina.Â  The agreement provided BPD would receive minimum compensation of $24,000.00 for architectural services and at least $24,000.00 for construction services.Â 
 
On October 14, 2005, BPD filed a Notice of Mechanicâ€™s Lien upon the property for $16,607.09 for labor performed and materials provided to Benchmark.Â  The notice was accompanied by a Verification of Statement of Account signed by BPDâ€™s president.Â  The Notice of Mechanicâ€™s Lien and the Verification of Statement of Account were served upon the registered agent for Benchmark, Charles Smith, on October 13, 2005.Â 
 
Smith gave the documentation to C.D. Candler, the president of Benchmark.Â  Candler met with his attorney regarding the mechanicâ€™s lien and was reportedly instructed that he did not need to take action unless a lawsuit was filed to foreclose the lien.Â 
 
On November 29, 2005, BPD filed a summons and complaint against Benchmark asserting claims for foreclosure of the mechanicâ€™s lien and breach of contract.Â  BPD sought $16,607.09 for the lien, plus interest, attorneyâ€™s fees, and costs.Â  On the breach of contract claim, BPD sought $61,170.70, plus interest and costs.Â  The same day, BPD also filed a lis pendens.Â  Â Â 
According to an Affidavit of Service, Smith was served with these pleadings on December 10, 2005.Â  In his own affidavit, Smith admitted being served on December 10th, but stated that he thought the documents were â€œthe same as the original mechanic[â€™]s lien,â€ so he left a copy of them on Candlerâ€™s desk.Â  At that time, both Candler and Benchmarkâ€™s attorney were out of the country.Â  On January 13, 2006, having received no answer to the pleadings or request for an extension of time, BPD filed an affidavit of default.Â  Â Â 
The Honorable G.E. Welmaker filed an Order of Default and Order of Reference on February 13, 2006, finding Benchmark had not answered or otherwise filed a response to the pleadings and therefore was in default. Judge Welmaker separated the mechanicâ€™s lien and the breach of contract actions and referred the mechanicâ€™s lien claim to the Master-In-Equity for Greenville County â€œto make findings of fact and conclusions of law; dispose of any and all issues and enter a final judgment in the case; order a judicial sale on any day . . . ; [and] hear and dispose of any issues after sale or judgment . . . .â€Â  In the same order, Judge Welmaker stated the claim for breach of contract â€œhas been or will be resolved by the issuance of a default judgment.â€Â  Thereafter, Judge Welmaker filed a separate Order for Judgment by Default on March 1, 2006, granting BPD a default judgment against Benchmark for $61,170.70 for its breach of contract claim.Â 
 
On March 1, 2006, BPDâ€™s attorney mailed a Notice of Hearing to Benchmark advising it that a hearing regarding the mechanicâ€™s lien claim had been scheduled before the Master-In-Equity on March 23, 2006, following which a final judgment would be issued.Â  After receiving this notice, Candler searched his office and discovered the 2005 pleadings on his desk.Â  Â Â 
On March 21, 2006, Benchmark filed a â€œMotion to Set Aside Default Pursuant to Rule[s] 55 and 60 of SCRCPâ€ asking the court to set aside the default judgment â€œon the grounds that the Defendant[â€™]s neglect in [a]nswering the Complaint is excusable; that the Complaint does not properly and adequately verify the damages by verified statement of account; [and] even if the statement of account is proper the damages verified are patently inconsistent on their face and the [D]efendant has a meritorious defense.â€Â Â Â  Â Â 
The master held a hearing regarding the claim for foreclosure of the mechanicâ€™s lien as scheduled on March 23, 2006.Â  At the start of the hearing, BPDâ€™s counsel was made aware, for the first time, of Benchmarkâ€™s motion regarding the default and stated she had not been served with a copy of it.Â  Benchmarkâ€™s attorney noted the motion was â€œon its wayâ€ to BPD.Â  The master stated the hearing would go on as scheduled, explaining, â€œ[A]t this point I donâ€™t have any basis to do anything other than proceed.â€Â Â  Benchmarkâ€™s attorney expressly consented to continuation of the hearing on the foreclosure.Â  The parties thereafter focused solely on the amount of attorneyâ€™s fees that should be awarded on the mechanicâ€™s lien action, with Benchmarkâ€™s attorney questioning BPDâ€™s attorney as to the basis for the amount claimed.Â  Benchmark did not specifically dispute any of the other amounts sought in the mechanicâ€™s lien action at the hearing.Â  Â 
The master filed a Decree for Foreclosure of Mechanicâ€™s Lien on March 28, 2006, awarding $16,607.09 for foreclosure of the lien, $4,000.00 for attorneyâ€™s fees, plus interest and costs, for a total judgment of $21,974.64.Â  The master noted the default judgment obtained for breach of contract was â€œa separate debt owed by the Defendant, completely unrelated to the debt established herein, as secured by a mechanicâ€™s lien.â€[2]Â   
On April 6, 2006, the master held a hearing on Benchmarkâ€™s motion regarding the default.Â  The master initially discussed the fact that Benchmarkâ€™s motion was made pursuant to both Rule 55 and Rule 60 of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure, but the master stated he believed Rule 60 would then be applicable â€œsince the default was already entered.â€Â  None of the parties objected to the application of Rule 60, and they proceeded to argue whether â€œexcusable neglectâ€ had been established as required under the rule.[3]Â   
In early May 2006, the master denied Benchmarkâ€™s motion for relief from the default judgment, finding Benchmark had not established â€œexcusable neglectâ€ under Rule 60(b), SCRCP.Â  Prior to this ruling, Benchmark had filed on April 27, 2006 a motion to alter or amend the judgment for foreclosure of the mechanicâ€™s lien, arguing the award of $4,000.00 for attorneyâ€™s fees was excessive.Â  The master denied this motion on May 23, 2006, finding the amount of the attorneyâ€™s fees awarded was appropriate.Â 
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Default Judgment
On appeal, Benchmark argues the master â€œabused [his] discretion in not setting aside the defaultâ€ because Benchmark demonstrated it acted promptly upon receiving notice of the default judgment, its neglect was excusable, and it had a meritorious defense.[4] Â 
Rule 60(b)
â€œThe proper procedure for challenging a default judgment is to move the trial court to set aside the judgment pursuant to Rule 60(b), SCRCP.â€Â  Winesett v. Winesett, 287 S.C. 332, 334, 338 S.E.2d 340, 341 (1985).Â  Rule 60(b)(1) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure permits a court to relieve a party from a final judgment upon a finding of mistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect.Â  Rule 60(b)(1), SCRCP.Â  The movant must also show a meritorious defense.Â  Tri-County Ice & Fuel Co. v. Palmetto Ice Co., 303 S.C. 237, 242, 399 S.E.2d 779, 782 (1990).Â Â Â  
 
â€œWhether to grant or deny a motion under Rule 60(b) lies within the sound discretion of the judge.â€Â  BB & T v. Taylor, 369 S.C. 548, 551, 633 S.E.2d 501, 502 (2006).Â  â€œOur standard of review, therefore, is limited to determining whether there was an abuse of discretion.â€Â  Id. at 551, 633 S.E.2d at 502-03.Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion arises where the judge issuing the order was controlled by an error of law or where the order is based on factual conclusions that are without evidentiary support.â€Â  Id. at 551, 633 S.E.2d at 503.
A party seeking to set aside a judgment pursuant to Rule 60(b) has the burden of presenting evidence to support the claim for relief.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 304 S.C. 65, 67, 403 S.E.2d 127, 129 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  In this case, Benchmark contends the judgment should be set aside for excusable neglect.Â  â€œExcusable neglectâ€ is generally defined as follows:

	A failure â€“ which the law will excuse â€“ to take some proper step at the proper time (esp. in neglecting to answer a lawsuit) not because of the partyâ€™s own carelessness, inattention, or willful disregard of the courtâ€™s process, but because of some unexpected or unavoidable hindrance or accident . . . .

Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 1055 (7th ed. 1999).Â   
In this case, the registered agent for Benchmark, Charles Smith, was served with the pleadings for foreclosure of the mechanicâ€™s lien on or about December 10, 2005.Â  Smith incorrectly assumed these documents were the same as the original Notice of Mechanicâ€™s Lien, and he placed the pleadings on Candlerâ€™s desk.Â  The pleadings remained on Candlerâ€™s desk until he discovered them several months later in March 2006, well after the time allowed for a responsive pleading.Â  Benchmarkâ€™s explanation for its failure to take any action on the pleadings is that Smith did not recognize these were new pleadings; Candler, Benchmarkâ€™s president, was on his honeymoon in South America in December 2005; and Benchmarkâ€™s attorney was also out of the country for part of this time.Â 
 
In denying the motion to set aside the default judgment, the master found â€œ[t]he registered agent failed to take notice of the language in the [s]ummons which alerted him to the nature of the proceedings and the results of inaction.â€Â  The master determined the registered agentâ€™s â€œalleged mistake in believing the lis pendens, summons and complaint to be the same as the mechanicâ€™s lien does not amount to excusable neglect, as â€˜[l]ack of familiarity with legal proceedings is unacceptable and the court will not hold a layman to any lesser standard than is applied to an attorney,â€™â€ quoting Hill v. Dotts, 345 S.C. 304, 310, 547 S.E.2d 894, 897 (Ct. App. 2001).[5]Â  Â Â 
The master further noted that â€œ[c]onfusion over litigation does not, by itself, warrant relief from default.â€Â  The master stated BPD â€œwould be prejudiced by the delay in the sale and lost expense attributed to the advertisement if the Court were to set aside the default judgment.â€Â  The master concluded â€œthat [Benchmark] has failed to show excusable neglect as required under Rule 60(b) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.â€Â  
 
We find there is evidence to support the masterâ€™s determination and hold the master properly exercised his discretion in not setting aside the default judgment based on excusable neglect.Â  In this case, Benchmark had a duty to monitor the progress of its case, especially since it was aware that a Notice of Mechanicâ€™s Lien had already been filed and it was on notice to expect an action to foreclose the lien.Â  The registered agentâ€™s failure to recognize and appreciate the significance of the pleadings seeking foreclosure of the lien and his mistaken belief those pleadings were additional copies of the original Notice of Mechanicâ€™s Lien is not the type of neglect that is excusable under Rule 60(b).Â  
 
Based on the foregoing, we affirm the masterâ€™s ruling upholding the default judgment.Â  See Stewart v. Floyd, 274 S.C. 437, 440-41, 265 S.E.2d 254, 255-56 (1980) (affirming the trial courtâ€™s refusal to set aside a default judgment where the defendant, a practicing physician, contended he received two sets of summons and complaints that were so similar that it constituted excusable neglect for him to conclude the second set had been taken care of by the fact that he had given the first set to his attorneys; our supreme court noted that, in this case, the defendantâ€™s attorneys and his malpractice carrier â€œwere alert to the fact that a second action would probably be forthcomingâ€); DeNault v. Holloway Builders, Inc., 271 S.C. 468, 470, 248 S.E.2d 265, 266 (1978) (holding a corporate presidentâ€™s confusion over receiving two complaints in the same week and his mistaken assumption that service had occurred the same day, thus resulting in the late service of an answer, did not constitute excusable neglect to set aside a default judgment, the court stating â€œ[i]n such situations, neglect is present but not excusable neglect entitling a party to relief from a default judgmentâ€); cf. Mitchell Supply Co. v. Gaffney, 297 S.C. 160, 375 S.E.2d 321 (Ct. App. 1988) (holding the debtors were not entitled to relief from a default judgment on the basis their attorney failed to properly review the pleadings that were delivered to him; the attorneyâ€™s neglect was attributable to the client and did not constitute the type of neglect that was excusable under Rule 60(b), SCRCP).
Damages Hearing
Benchmark further argues the master â€œerred in not setting aside the judgment and requiring a damage[s] hearing, the error being that there was no verified statement of account, the claim was unliquidated as a matter of law[,] and the verified pleadings failed to set forth damages in a manner that could be readily ascertained.â€Â  Benchmark argues the amount requested was â€œa sum which can only be made certain by computation.â€Â Â Â 
 
In establishing the amount due under the mechanicâ€™s lien, the master, citing Rule 55, SCRCP, observed, â€œThe present case involved liquidated damages, and Plaintiff properly and adequately verified those damages through a verified statement of account. . . .Â  A hearing on the damages claimed by Plaintiff is not necessary as the Lis Pendens, Summons and Complaint were properly and adequately verified by a verified statement of account.â€Â 
 
Damages are said to be liquidated where â€œthe sum is certain or capable of being reduced to certainty based on a mathematical calculation previously agreed to by the parties.â€Â  Vaughn Dev., Inc. v. Westvaco Dev. Corp., Â 372 S.C. 576, 579-580, 642 S.E.2d 757, 759 (Ct. App. 2007).

	Rule 55(b)(1), SCRCP provides as follows:
	
		When the claim of a party seeking judgment by default is for a liquidated amount, a sum certain or a sum which can by computation be made certain, the judge, upon motion or application of the party seeking default, and upon affidavit of the amount due, shall enter judgment for that amount and costs against the party against whom judgment by default is sought, if that party has been defaulted for failure to appear . . . .Â  A verified pleading may be used in lieu of an affidavit when the pleading contains information sufficient to determine or compute the sum certain. 
		
	

At the hearing on March 23, 2006, the master heard testimony regarding the mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  Counsel for both BPD and Benchmark were in attendance.Â  Benchmarkâ€™s counsel examined BPDâ€™s counsel regarding her claimed attorneyâ€™s fees, but did not dispute any of the other amounts BPD had requested.Â  Thus, Benchmarkâ€™s counsel had an opportunity to dispute the requested damages prior to the filing of the order foreclosing the mechanicâ€™s lien on March 28, 2006.Â  Benchmarkâ€™s argument that the default judgment should be set aside because of the lack of a damages hearing is, therefore, without merit.
Additionally, the master did not err in issuing a default judgment because the pleadings were, in any event, verified and requested a definite amount.Â  BPDâ€™s complaint included a specific demand for $16,607.00, plus prejudgment interest, attorneyâ€™s fees, and costs.Â  The complaint incorporated by reference the Notice of Mechanicâ€™s Lien, which included a description of Benchmarkâ€™s property.Â  The pleadings included a Verification of Statement of Account signed by BPDâ€™s president stating the complaint and allegations were true to the best of his knowledge.Â  They also included a copy of the partiesâ€™ agreement, which set forth the guidelines for minimum compensation.Â  The computations may be difficult, but the pleadings provided guidance and verification.Â Â 
 
Viewed together, these documents satisfy the verification requirements for a mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  See Taylor Freezer Sales Co. v. Bachman, 285 S.C. 292, 296, 329 S.E.2d 1, 3 (Ct. App. 1985) (observing that, in determining if a statement of account is satisfactory, the complaint, statement of account, and verification must be considered together); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-90 (2007) (noting a statement of account should contain â€œa just and true account of the amount due [], with all just credits given, together with a description of the property intended to be covered by the lien sufficiently accurate for identification, with the name of the owner of the property, if known, which certificate shall be subscribed and sworn to by the person claiming the lien or by someone [o]n his behalfâ€); see also Rule 9(i), SCRCP (regarding verifications of accounts, stating â€œ[i]n an action on an account the pleader shall attach a verified copy of the account to the pleading, or if the items of the account are set forth in the pleading, it must be verifiedâ€).
In cases where the amount of damages is not certain, â€œthe court may conduct such hearing or order such references as it deems necessary and proper . . . .â€Â  Rule 55(b)(2), SCRCP (emphasis added).Â  Thus, if the master did not believe these were liquidated damages, the master had the discretion to explore these amounts or to examine the parties further, but it is clear from the record that the master did not find it necessary to go beyond what the parties addressed at the hearing, namely, the amount of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We conclude the parties did have an opportunity to examine BPD regarding the amounts requested at the scheduled hearing and, further, that a hearing was not required in any case as the amounts sought were verified and ascertainable.Â  Accordingly, the default judgment for the mechanicâ€™s lien should not be set aside.
II.Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Benchmark next argues the master erred in granting the full amount of attorneyâ€™s fees requested by BPDâ€™s counsel in the mechanicâ€™s lien action because the amount was excessive.Â  Benchmark specifically asserts that some of the time billed pertained to the breach of contract claim, for which attorneyâ€™s fees are not recoverable.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â 
Under South Carolina law, â€œ[t]he costs which may arise in enforcing or defending against the [mechanicâ€™s] lien under this chapter, including a reasonable attorneyâ€™s fee, may be recovered by the prevailing party.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-10(a) (2007).Â  â€œThe fee must be determined by the court in which the action is brought but the fee and the court costs may not exceed the amount of the lien.â€Â  Id.Â  
 
â€œThe determination as to the amount of attorney fees which should be awarded under the mechanicâ€™s lien statute is addressed to the sound discretion of the trial court and its decision will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.â€Â  Seckinger v. Vessel Excalibur, 326 S.C. 382, 386, 483 S.E.2d 775, 777 (Ct. App. 1997).
In determining a reasonable fee, a court should consider the following six factors:Â  â€œ1) nature, extent, and difficulty of the legal services rendered; 2) time and labor devoted to the case; 3) professional standing of counsel; 4) contingency of compensation; 5) fee customarily charged in the locality for similar services; and 6) beneficial results obtained.â€Â  Blumberg v. Nealco, Inc., 310 S.C. 492, 494, 427 S.E.2d 659, 660 (1993); see also Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991) (addressing the factors to be considered in determining a reasonable attorneyâ€™s fee).
BPDâ€™s attorney, Sara Hutchins, submitted an affidavit requesting $4,000.00 as a reasonable attorneyâ€™s fee for the mechanicâ€™s lien claim.Â  Counsel stated she worked twenty-four hours on the case at a rate of $150.00 per hour, and she anticipated an additional three hours would be necessary following the hearing.Â  She also itemized costs of $850.00 incurred in the action.Â 
 
At the hearing on damages for the mechanicâ€™s lien, Benchmarkâ€™s attorney questioned Hutchins about the time she devoted solely to the mechanicâ€™s lien claim.Â  Hutchins explained that she prepared one complaint that included claims for both foreclosure of the mechanicâ€™s lien and breach of contract, and one lis pendens.Â  She stated any time that would indirectly be attributable to the breach of contract claim was minimal, however, as it ended in a default judgment.Â  Benchmark raised no objection to the amount of costs itemized in the affidavit.[6]Â  
 
In awarding BPD attorneyâ€™s fees and again in addressing Benchmarkâ€™s motion to alter or amend, the master expressly considered the relevant factors in Blumberg before finding $4,000.00 was â€œa reasonable attorneyâ€™s fee for the Plaintiffâ€™s attorney for services performed and anticipated to be performed until final adjudication of the within action.â€Â  In making the award, the master noted the fee covered â€œthe time and labor devoted to the case, including reviewing the various loan documents, performing the title search, preparing, filing and serving the Mechanicâ€™s Lien and the pleadings herein[,]â€ as well as â€œpreparing for the hearing, including preparing this decree and other documents requested by the Court, attending the hearing, preparing for and attending the sale, and preparing any post-sale documents requested by the Court.â€Â  
 
Testimony at the hearing, Hutchinsâ€™s affidavit, Benchmarkâ€™s continued intertwining of the two claims, and the number of pleadings, motions, and hearings involved, all support the masterâ€™s decision to award BPD $4,000.00 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Accordingly, we hold the master considered the appropriate factors and did not abuse his discretion in awarding $4,000.00 in attorneyâ€™s fees to BPD.
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Â At the foreclosure hearing, BPDâ€™s counsel stated the breach of contract claim was for architectural fees, whereas the mechanicâ€™s lien was for construction and contracting services provided.Â  Counsel stated the amount requested for the mechanicâ€™s lien was â€œnot included in the judgment by default [BPD] received on the breach of contract issue.â€Â 
 
[3]Â  See Fickling v. City of Charleston, 372 S.C. 597, 601, 643 S.E.2d 110, 112 (Ct. App. 2007) (stating a trial courtâ€™s ruling on an issue becomes the law of the case where the appellant fails to take exception to it both before the trial court and on appeal). 
 
[4]Â  The notice of appeal challenges three orders issued by the master regarding BPDâ€™s claim for foreclosure of a mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  To the extent Benchmarkâ€™s brief can be construed as raising issues regarding the default judgment for breach of contract, we note these issues are not properly before us.Â  The circuit court, in a separate order, entered the default judgment for the breach of contract claim.Â  The only claim referred to the master was for foreclosure of the mechanicâ€™s lien, and that is the only matter addressed in the masterâ€™s orders.Â  Accordingly, we make no determination regarding the breach of contract claim.
[5] Â In Hill, the defendantâ€™s mother sent a letter to the plaintiff on the defendantâ€™s behalf after the defendant received the complaint, but the defendant did not serve a responsive pleading.Â  Id. at 306-07, 547 S.E.2d at 895.Â  We held the defendantâ€™s â€œfailure to understand the legal process is [not] a sufficient reason to excuse his tardy reply.â€Â  Id. at 310, 547 S.E.2d at 897.Â  We noted a party has a duty to monitor the progress of his case and to timely respond when duly served with a summons and complaint.Â  Id.Â  
 
[6]Â  To the extent Benchmark attempts on appeal to contest the amount of costs awarded and to argue the total included costs that were not recoverable, no issue is preserved in this regard.Â  See, e.g., Washington v. Whitaker, 317 S.C. 108, 114, 451 S.E.2d 894, 898 (1994) (â€œ[I]t is well settled that a contemporaneous objection must be made to preserve an argument for appellate review.â€).

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE AND SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Roosevelt Eison, Petitioner
				v.
				State of South Carolina, Respondent
			
		
	


Appeal From Union County
Â Lee S. Alford, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2007-UP-348
Submitted June 1, 2007 â€“ Filed July 6, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Roosevelt Eison, Pro Se, Â for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Julie M. Thames, Office of the Attorney General, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Following his conviction and subsequent direct appeal, Eison filed his initial petition for writ of habeas corpus on May 23, 1996.Â  This petition was construed by the circuit court to be a PCR.Â  Following a hearing, the circuit court dismissed the action.Â  Eison appealed the dismissal to the Supreme Court, but his petition for writ of certiorari was denied onÂ  December 29, 1998.
 
Eison then filed a petition for writ of habeas corpus in the South Carolina Supreme Court on January 5, 1999.Â  His petition was denied on February 5, 1999.Â  Eison then filed a petition for writ of habeas corpus in federal court on March 11, 1999.Â  That petition was dismissed by the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals on June 6, 2000.Â  Eison then filed another petition for writ of habeas corpus in the circuit court on October 11, 2000.Â  A PCR hearing was held, and Eisonâ€™s petition was dismissed on June 26, 2001.Â  Eison appealed the dismissal to the Supreme Court, but his petition for writ of certiorari was denied on February 21, 2003.Â 
 
Eison filed the instant petition for writ of habeas corpus on February 20, 2004, in the circuit court.Â  In this petition, Eison contended he had been â€œdenied due process of law in violation of the federal constitutionâ€™s fourteenth amendment by the state knowingly presenting false testimony; failing to disclose exculpatory, impeachment, and mitigating information.â€Â  By order filed March 14, 2005, the circuit court dismissed the petition because Eison was procedurally barred from filing a petition for writ of habeas corpus in a circuit court. The court also found that the Supreme Court was the proper place for him to file his petition for writ of habeas corpus due to the matter he alleged entitled him to relief being a matter which could have been filed in a PCR action.Â  The court went on to review the action as a PCR and found that it should be dismissed even if treated as a PCR because it wasÂ  successive and filed untimely pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-45(a).Â  This appeal follows.
Eison claims the circuit court erred in failing to order the State to respond to his subpoenas and discovery motion before dismissing the action.Â  He also claims the circuit court violated his procedural and substantive due process by failing to abide by established rules and procedures.Â  We affirm the circuit courtâ€™s decision pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and the following authorities: Keller v. Mauney, 330 S.C. 568, 500 S.E.2d 123 (Ct. App. 1998) (holding that a person whose claim for relief could have been raised in a PCR application is procedurally barred from petitioning a circuit for a writ of habeas corpus and his only means of seeking such a writ is in the original jurisdiction of the Supreme Courtâ€); Gibson v. State, 329 S.C. 37, 495 S.E.2d 426 (1998) (stating a petition for a writ of habeas corpus can be treated as a PCR application); Aice v. State, 305 S.C. 448, 409 S.E.2d 392
  (1991) (stating â€œsuccessive applications for relief are not to be entertained, and the burden shall be on the applicant to establish that any new ground raised in a subsequent application could not have been raised by him in the previous application.â€); Peloquin v. State, 321 S.C. 468, 469 S.E.2d 606
  (1996) (applying the one year statute of limitations contained in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-45); Bayle v. South Carolina Dept. of Transp.,  344 S.C. 115, 128-129, 542 S.E.2d 736, 743 (Ct. App. 2001) (stating that the trial judge did not abuse his discretion in quashing the motion for additional discovery and granting summary judgment where appellant failed to â€œdemonstrate further discovery would have contributed to the resolution of the issue at hand, whether the statute of limitations barred [the] action.â€).
Accordingly, the order of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.[1]
STILWELL, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Alford v. Tamsberg
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Virginia W. Alford, Appellant,
				v.
				Joseph L. Tamsberg, Jr. and State of South Carolina, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Roger M. Young, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2007-UP-350
Heard May 9, 2007 â€“ Filed July 6, 2007Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Donald Jay Budman, of Charleston, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Deputy Attorney General T. Stephen Lynch, Assistant Deputy Attorney General J. Emory Smith, Jr., all of Columbia and David M. Swanson, Marvin D. Infinger and Julie O. Medich, all of Charleston, for Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  In this action to try title, Virginia Alford argues the master in equity erred in finding Joseph Tamsberg established title to marshlands through adverse possession.Â  She also contends the master erred in (1) finding res judicata barred her claim; (2) denying her motion for a new trial; and (3) dismissing her claim for trespass.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Alford and Tamsberg are adjoining landowners.Â  Both properties consist of highlands and marshlands.Â  At issue in this case is a 150 acre tract of marshland that is, essentially, all of the marshland Tamsberg owns, which Alford claims title to.Â  Alford also claims the boundary line in the center of a canal, or ditch as it is often referred to, between the highland portion of the two properties is incorrect (Highland Dispute).Â  She alleges the boundary line should be placed on the northern side of the canal on Tamsbergâ€™s property.
Alford can directly trace the title to her property back to 1839, to a deed from Thomas Butler to her relative, Thaddeus C. Skrine. Â Â Prior to 1951, Tamsbergâ€™s property consisted of two parcels of land owned by Belmont Land and Investment Company (Belmont Land).Â  In 1951 the first known survey (Belmont Survey) of the two parcels was commissioned.Â  On April 18, 1956, Belmont Land conveyed the two parcels, as shown on the 1951 Belmont Survey, to Belmont Hosiery Mills, Inc. (Belmont Hosiery).Â  
 
In 1961, Alford commenced an action against Belmont Hosiery, for recovery of 40 acres of marshland.Â  The parties settled the suit by Belmont Hosiery quitclaiming the disputed 40 acres to Alford.Â  The marshlands deeded to Alford were depicted on the settlement plat prepared by W.S. Gaillard.Â  After the parties reached the settlement, the trial court dismissed Alfordâ€™s claim with prejudice.Â  

In 1967, Alford commissioned Gaillard to prepare a survey of her property.Â  In 1968, Alford consolidated all her property â€œinto one deed and one plat.â€Â  The deed identified the property â€œas fully described and delineated by a plat of W.L. Gaillard, Surveyor, dated April 1967â€Â  (1967 Alford Survey).
 
On May 30, 1968, Belmont Hosiery conveyed the land, minus the 40 acres of marshland deeded to Alford, to Heritage Development CompanyÂ  (Heritage). Â Â By a Certificate of Merger, Heritage merged into Parkdale Mills, Inc., (Parkdale), Tamsbergâ€™s immediate predecessor.Â  On January 30, 1990, Tamsberg purchased the property from Parkdale.Â Â  For this purchase, Tamsberg had a survey prepared by Luckey Sanders (1990 Tamsberg Survey).Â  All of the surveys since 1951, including the 1967 Alford Survey, show the boundary lines of the adjoining property as depicted on the 1951 Belmont Survey prepared by Gaillard.Â  
 
On January 26, 2000, Alford initiated this action, seeking to quiet title to a part of Tamsbergâ€™s marshlands.Â  She also sought to quiet the boundary between the adjoining lands.Â  The case was referred to the master, and on September 14, 2000, the partiesâ€™ partially tried the case.Â  Shortly thereafter, the parties reached a settlement.Â  Alford moved to have the settlement quashed, and the master granted her motion.Â  Due to the complexity of the case, Alford received numerous extensions.Â  

On February, 14, 2002, the master concluded that because the parties disputed title to marshlands, the State of South Carolina, as presumptive owner of all tidelands, would have to be made a party to the case.Â  On January 28, 2003, Alford amended her complaint to reflect her finding of a 1797 grant from the State of South Carolina to Skrineâ€™s immediate predecessor in title, Joseph Butler (Butler Grant).Â  Essentially, Alford claimed that because she showed her title emanated from a grant from the State and Tamsberg could not trace his title back to a grant from the State, she owned all of Tamsbergâ€™s marshlands.Â  

a hearing on June 18 and 19, 2003, the master found the State of South Carolina had divested itself of any marshlands conveyed by the Butler Grant.Â  Therefore, the master found both Tamsberg and Alfordâ€™s claim to their respective marshes was superior to the Stateâ€™s claim.Â  Additionally, the master found the 1967 Alford Survey and the 1951 Belmont Survey both refer to the boundary line between the adjoining properties as â€œditch the line.â€ Â The master also found the unrecorded 1886 Royall Plat also placed the boundary line at the center. Â Accordingly, the master concluded that the surveys place the line in the center of the ditch.Â  Further, the master found the 1990 Tamsberg survey also described the boundary line as â€œditch on or near property line.â€Â  

As to the marshland, the master found all of the surveys were in agreement as to the boundary lines of the two properties.Â  The master found that Tamsbergâ€™s 60 year chain of title included the marshlands; however, his title could not be traced to Butler or Skrine.Â  Due to the doctrine of adverse possession, the master concluded that Tamsberg had ownership of the marsh through the presumption of a grant theory.Â  Additionally, the master found section 15-3-380 of the South Carolina Code (2005), the forty-year lapse statute, provided Tamsberg with good title.Â  Further, the master found Alford acquiesced to Tamsbergâ€™s use of the marshlands for 32 years.Â  Lastly, the master noted that res judicata barred Alfordâ€™s claim because of the previous suit with Tamsbergâ€™s predecessor in title, Belmont Hosiery.Â  

Alford filed a motion under Rule 59(e), SCRCP, to alter or amend the judgment, which the master denied.Â  The master also denied Alfordâ€™s motion for a new trial based on after discovered evidence.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Normally, an action to quiet title to property is one in equity.Â  Clark v. Hargrave, 323 S.C. 84, 86, 473 S.E.2d 474, 475 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  â€œHowever, the character, as legal or equitable, of an action is determined by the complaint in its main purpose, the nature of the issues as raised by the pleadings . . . and the character of the relief sought under them.â€Â  Id. (citing Ins. Fin. Serv., Inc., v. S.C. Ins. Co., 271 S.C. 289, 247 S.E.2d 315 (1978).Â  
 
Alford alleged in her complaint that Tamsberg owned no marshland and that she had superior title to his land.Â  Tamsberg, in his answer, responded that he possessed fee simple title to the marshlands and asserted adverse possession as an affirmative defense.Â  Because this action primarily involves the determination of title to real estate based on adverse possession, it is an action at law.Â  Id. at 87, 473 S.E.2d at 476 (holding an action primarily involving adverse possession can properly be characterized as an action at law). Â Additionally, a boundary dispute is an action at law.Â  Bodiford v. Spanish Oak Farms, Inc., 317 S.C. 539, 544, 455 S.E.2d 194, 197 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  â€œIn an action at law, on appeal of a case tried without a jury, the findings of fact of the judge will not be disturbed upon appeal unless found to be without evidence which reasonably supports the judges findings.â€Â  Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Highland Dispute  
Alford argues the master erred in placing the boundary line between the adjoining properties down the center of the ditch.Â  Alford argues the true boundary line, as depicted in the unrecorded 1886 Royall Plat, shows the boundary line is on the north side of the ditch.Â  We disagree. Â 
During the trial, Tamsberg presented Thomas Bessent, an expert in the field of land surveying.Â  Alford originally hired Bessent to resurvey the property because she questioned the boundary line between the adjoining properties.Â  Bessent testified he looked at the Belmont Survey, Alford Survey, and Tamsberg Survey, as well as the 1886 Royall Plat.Â  He then went to the property to conduct his own survey.Â  He opined the correct boundary line was the center of the ditch as depicted in the Belmont, Alford, and Tamsberg Surveys.Â  In Bessentâ€™s expert opinion, even the Royall Plat shows the boundary line as the center of the ditch.Â  He pointed out that the Royall Plat has a dashed black property line that clearly runs through the middle of the ditch.Â  At the end of that black line is the word â€œpost.â€Â  According to Bessent, the black line is marked by a post, in the center of the ditch.Â  

Alford presented Steve Johnson, also as an expert in surveying.Â  He opined the boundary line was on the northern side of the ditch on Tamsbergâ€™s property.Â  He testified that he used Alfordâ€™s parol evidence to help him establish the boundary line.
We hold that the record overwhelmingly supports the masterâ€™s finding that the boundary line is in the center of the ditch.Â  The evidence shows that all of the surveys, including the 1886 Royall Plat, relied on by Alford, shows the boundary line as the center of the ditch.Â  In fact, the only evidence to the contrary is Alfordâ€™s expert, Johnson, who admitted to using Alfordâ€™s parol testimony to â€œaidâ€ the rendition of his survey.Â  Accordingly, we find the master properly concluded the true boundary line between the adjoining properties is the center of the ditch, as depicted by the various surveys.Â 
 
II.Â  Adverse Possession 
Alford argues the master erred in finding Tamsberg obtained title to the marsh by adverse possession.Â  Specifically, Alford contends Tamsberg cannot show his title to the marsh derives from a grant from the State of South Carolina.Â  She maintains she can trace back her chain of title to a grant from the State, but that because she did not prove actual ownership of the marshlands until this litigation the presumption was the State owned the marsh.Â  Therefore, Alford argues Tamsbergâ€™s claim to the marsh by adverse possession could not accrue against her in the short time since she has established her title.Â  We disagree.
In South Carolina, the State is the presumptive owner of all tidelands.Â  State v. Yelsen Land Co., Inc., 265 S.C. 78, 81, 216 S.E.2d 876, 878 (1975).Â  A party wishing to rebut this presumption bears the burden of showing the State â€œgranted title to such lands to their predecessors in title.â€Â  Id. (citing State v. Pinckney, 22 S.C. 484 (1885); State v. Hardee, 259 S.C. 535, 193 S.E.2d 497 (1972)).Â  In addition, the doctrine of adverse possession cannot be used against the State.Â  Davis v. Monteith, 289 S.C. 176, 179-180, 345 S.E.2d 724, 276 (1986) (citations omitted).Â  Â Â Â 
In this case, the master found that on July 3, 1797, the State of South Carolina granted 325 acres of marshland to Joseph Butler, which included both Alfordâ€™s and Tamsbergâ€™s portion of the marsh.Â  Therefore, the master concluded that Alford and Tamsbergâ€™s claim to their respective parcels of marshland were superior to the Stateâ€™s claim.Â  The master also found that because Tamsbergâ€™s title to the marshlands cannot be specifically traced to the Butler Grant that, but for â€œa succession of events over the years, and many years of possession by Tamsberg and his predecessors in title, Alford would have a superior claim to Tamsbergâ€™s marshes.â€
Alfordâ€™s argument rests on the faulty premise that the State held actual title to the marshlands until she proved otherwise.Â  Under Alfordâ€™s reasoning, Tamsberg could not have adversely possessed against the State and, because she has held title for such a short time, Tamsberg is unable to satisfy the elements of adverse possession against her.Â  However, as noted above, title to marshlands in South Carolina is presumptively rather than actually vested in the State.Â  Alford, through diligent research, overcame the presumption and established the State granted marshlands to her predecessor in title in 1797.Â  Therefore, Alford and her predecessors in title have held title to the marshlands since 1797 and Tamsberg and his predecessors could use the doctrine of adverse possession to claim title to the land.Â  We now turn to examine whether Tamsberg has satisfied the elements of adverse possession.
In South Carolina, when a party shows â€œactual, hostile, exclusive, and continuous possessionâ€ of land for twenty years a presumption of grant is said to exist.Â  Haithcock v. Haithcock, 123 S.C. 61, 67, 115 S.E. 727, 729 (1923).Â  In addition, to satisfy the requisite period of time â€œthe time of possession may be tacked not only by ancestors and heirs, but also between parties in privity. . . .â€Â  Getsinger v. Midlands Orthopaedic Profit Sharing Plan, 327 S.C. 424, 430, 489 S.E.2d 223, 226 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  â€œThis common law presumption rests upon the theory that after a long period of peaceful possession, the possessor, or those under whom the possessor hold, will be presumed to have entered upon and possessed the property under a valid grant, now lost.â€Â  S.C. Juris. Adverse Possession Â§ 10 (citation omitted).Â  
 
The master found Tamsberg and his predecessors for at least forty-seven years have maintained, improved, and repaired the existing dikes which encompassed impoundments in the marshland. Â Â Tamsberg expended at least $100,000 on these activities since he purchased the property in 1990.Â  The master also found Tamsberg protected the marsh through caretakers he hired and with â€œno trespassingâ€ signs he posted.Â Â  The master also noted Tamsberg and his predecessors paid property taxes.Â  The master concluded Tamsberg and his predecessors were in open, continuous, actual, hostile, and exclusive possession of the marsh.Â  Accordingly, the master held Tamsberg satisfied the twenty-year common law presumption of a grant and held irrefutable title to the land.
 
Alford believes Tamsberg has not met the requisite element of â€œhostilityâ€ and, thus, cannot establish title to the marsh.Â  First, Alford maintains that Tamsberg cannot show his possession of the marsh was hostile to her because the State held title to the marsh until this litigation.Â  She believes the short amount of time that has transpired since the master declared she held legal title to the land was insufficient for Tamsberg to satisfy the hostility element.Â  For the reasons stated above, we find title to the marsh vested in Alfordâ€™s predecessors in 1797.Â  Accordingly, we findÂ  Alfordâ€™s argument on this point to be without merit.Â 
 
Second, Alford maintains because Tamsberg claimed throughout the course of this litigation he owned the marsh by virtue of his title, his claim of ownership is insufficient to establish hostile possession.Â  Alford relies on Cook v. Eller, 298 S.C. 395, 397, 380 S.E.2d 853, 854 (1989), for the proposition that possession under the mistaken belief a party owns a parcel of land is insufficient to establish hostility.Â  We find Alfordâ€™s reliance is misplaced.Â  As the South Carolina Supreme Court stated in Wigfall v. Fobbs, the mistaken belief rule is applicable only to cases involving boundary disputes between adjoining landowners.Â  295 S.C. 59, 61-62, 367 S.E.2d 156, 158 (1998).Â  Therefore, possession of land under a mistaken belief that property is oneâ€™s own can constitute hostile possession if the case involves a dispute over an entire tract of land. Â See Clark v. Hargrave, 323 S.C. 84, 89, 473 S.E.2d 474, 478 (Ct. App. 1996) (finding the mistaken belief rule inapplicable to a dispute over an entire tract of land).Â  Although Alford and Tamsberg are adjoining property owners, the dispute over the marshland is over an entire tract of land.Â  Accordingly, we find the mistaken belief rule does not apply and Tamsberg has satisfied the element of hostility.
Alford also contends Tamsbergâ€™s possession of the marsh has not been exclusive because she and her family have walked the property and posted â€œno trespassâ€ signs.Â  During trial, Tamsberg testified that he saw the â€œno trespassâ€ signs on his marsh, took them off, and carried them to Alfordâ€™s property.Â  Although the record is unclear, it appears the â€œno trespassâ€ signs were posted approximately the same time Alford filed suit.Â  We find Alfordâ€™s acts are insufficient to negate Tamsbergâ€™s and his predecessorsâ€™ exclusive possession of the property.Â  As noted earlier, Tamsberg improved and maintained the property. Â Further, he testified during the time he made the improvements Alford never informed him she believed she owned the property.Â  In addition, Tamsberg placed a conservation easement on his entire tract of land, including the marsh.Â  Accordingly, we find Tamsbergâ€™s acts are consistent with exclusive ownership of the marsh.
Moreover, the master held Tamsberg and his predecessors had satisfied section 15-3-380 of the South Carolina Code (2005), the forty-year lapse statute.Â  The statute provides a party cannot commence an action for â€œthe recovery of real property or for interest therein against a person in possession under a claim of titleÂ  . . . unless the person claiming, his ancestor, or grantor, was actually in possession of the same . . . within forty years from the commencement of such action.â€Â  Further, section 15-3-380 permits tacking. S.C. Juris. Adverse Possession Â§ 19; see Sutton v. Clark, 59 S.C. 440, 454, 38 S.E. 150, 156 (1901) (finding that Â§15-3-380â€™s predecessor Code 1962 Â§10-129 permits the tacking of the time a party has been in possession with the time during which those under whom he claims held possession).Â  
 
The master found, and we so hold, Tamsberg and his predecessors have been in possession for at least forty-seven years.Â  Since at least 1956, when Belmont Hosiery consolidated two tracts to form what is now Tamsbergâ€™s property, Tamsberg and his predecessors have continually possessed the property at issue in this case.Â  During this time period, Tamsberg and his predecessors have hunted, maintained, improved, and hired caretakers to keep trespassers off the land.Â Â  Therefore, because Tamsberg has been in possession of the marsh since his 1990 purchase of the land, and he and his predecessors were in possession since at least 1956, and neither Alford nor her predecessors were in possession of the marshland for the previous forty year statutory period, we find the master properly held Tamsberg acquired title to the marsh under section 15-3-380.
Alford also argues the master erred in finding the boundary to the marshlands was established as a matter of acquiescence.Â  She contends she always objected to Tamsbergâ€™s ownership of the marshlands.Â  Because we affirm the masterâ€™s order on the basis that Tamsberg established ownership of the marshlands through the presumption of a grant theory and the forty-year lapse statute, we find it unnecessary to reach Alfordâ€™s argument on this point.  Matthews v. Dennis, 365 S.C. 245, 248 n.2, 616 S.E.2d 437, 439 n.2 (Ct. App. 2005); see also Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (holding an appellate court need not review remaining issues when its determination of a prior issue is dispositive of the appeal).
III.Â  Res Judicata
Alford argues the master erred in finding res judicata barred her claim. She also contends that in the first action, the State was an indispensable party to the suit involving marshlands and was not made a party.Â  She maintains res judicata cannot apply to actions where all necessary parties are not joined.Â  We disagree.
Initially, we note Alfordâ€™s argument regarding the State as an indispensable party is not preserved for our review.Â  To preserve an issue for appellate review, the issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.Â  Charleston County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Jackson  368 S.C. 87, 104-05, 627 S.E.2d 765, 775 (Ct. App. 2006) (citing Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000) (â€œIt is well-settled that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved for appellate review)).Â  Alford did not raise this argument to the master.Â  Additionally, although Alfordâ€™s Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion did raise an assignment of error on the ground of res judicata, Alford did not raise the issue of the State as an indispensable party to the first action.Â  Therefore, this issue is not preserved.Â  See Washington v. Washington, 308 S.C. 549, 551, 419 S.E.2d 779, 781 (1992) (holding when an appellant neither raises an issue at trial nor through a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion to amend, the issue is not properly presented to an appellate court for review).Â  Therefore, we decline to address whether the fact the State was not a party to the first action precludes the application of res judicata against Alford.
We now turn to address whether res judicata bars Alfordâ€™s claim.Â Â  Under the doctrine of res judicata, a litigant is barred from raising issues previously adjudicated between the parties in a subsequent action.Â  See Hilton Head Ctr. of S.C., Inc. v. Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n of S.C., 294 S.C. 9, 11, 362 S.E.2d 176, 177 (1987).Â  Additionally, the doctrine of res judicata bars a litigant from raising any issues which may have been raised in the first action.Â  Pye v. Aycock,  325 S.C. 426, 432, 480 S.E.2d 455, 458 (Ct. App.Â  1997)Â  Res judicata requires three elements: (1) a judgment that is final, valid, and on the merits; (2) the parties in the second action are identical to those in the first; and (3) the subsequent action must involve a subject matter properly included in the first action.Â  See Owenby v. Owens Corning Fiberglas, 313 S.C. 181, 183, 437 S.E.2d 130, 132 (Ct. App. 1993) (citing Laffitte v. Tucker, 216 S.C. 201, 57 S.E.2d 255 (1950)).Â  
 
In 1961, Alford brought suit against Tamsbergâ€™s predecessor in title, Belmont Hosiery, alleging she owned 40 acres of Belmont Hosieryâ€™s marshlands.Â  As part of a settlement in that suit, Belmont Hosiery gave Alford a quitclaim deed for the forty acres.Â  The deed provided, in part, â€œAlford acknowledges that by the acceptance of this quit-claim deed she has released Belmont Hosiery Mills, Inc., its successors and assigns, from any and all claims and demands whatsoever that she may have to the dates of these presents . . . .â€Â  On April 18, 1968, the trial court issued an order dismissing Alfordâ€™s complaint with prejudice.Â  The order provided that Alford was â€œforever barred from claiming or to make claim of the [d]efendant for damages . . . in respect to any of the matters and things set forth in the [c]omplaint in this cause.â€ Â Relying on the trial courtâ€™s dismissal and the settlement deed, the master concluded res judicata barred Alfordâ€™s claim.Â  

The first suit was dismissed with prejudice which served as an adjudication on the merits.Â  See RIM Assocs. v. Blackwell, 359 S.C. 170, 182, 597 S.E.2d 152, 159 (Ct. App. 2004) (quoting Nelson v. QHG of S.C., Inc., 354 S.C. 290, 311, 580 S.E.2d 171, 182 (Ct. App. 2003) (â€œA case that is dismissed â€˜with prejudiceâ€™ indicates an adjudication on the merits and, pursuant to res judicata, prohibits subsequent litigation to the same extent as if the action had been tried to a final adjudication.â€)).Â  Secondly, although Tamsberg was not involved in the first suit, we find he and Belmont Hosiery were in privity, and therefore, Tamsbergâ€™s legal interests were litigated in the first action.Â  See Richburg v. Baughman, 290 S.C. 431, 434, 351 S.E.2d 164, 166 (1986) (â€œOne in privity is one whose legal interests were litigated in the former proceeding.); see also First Natâ€™l. Bank of Greenville v. U. S. Fid. & Guar. Co., 207 S.C. 15, 26, 35 S.E.2d 47, 53 (1945) (â€œâ€˜[P]rivity means a mutual or successive relationship to the same rights of property.â€™â€) (citation omitted).Â  Therefore, we find the master properly concluded res judicata bars Alfordâ€™s claim.Â 
 
Alford next argues that because the issue of ownership of the marshland pursuant to the 1797 Butler Grant was not raised in the first action, that the issues in the current litigation are different from those in the first action.Â  Essentially, she argues because she was unaware she owned all of Tamsbergâ€™s marshlands during the first suit that res judicata should not operate to defeat her claim.Â 
 
In the first action, Alford attempted to prove title to forty acres of marshland.Â  At that time, she could have brought suit alleging she owned all of the marshland because the 1797 Butler Grant was located in the public records. In 1961, during the first suit, she could have thoroughly researched her title and brought the current suit.Â  Therefore, we find Alford could have brought a claim for all of the marshlands in the first suit.Â  We also note res judicata is based upon â€œthe principle that the public interest requires an end of litigation.â€ Price v. City of Georgetown,  297 S.C. 185, 187, 375 S.E.2d 335, 337 (Ct. App. 1988) (citations omitted).Â  We find the third element, whether the subsequent action involves the same subject matter as the first, has been met because both actions involved title to the marshlands.Â  Accordingly, the master did not err in finding res judicata barred Alfordâ€™s claim.
Additionally, as an alternate sustaining ground we find that by accepting the quitclaim settlement deed, Alford agreed to release Belmont Hosiery, and its successors and assigns from all future claims regarding the disputed property.Â  See Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 418, 526 S.E.2d 716, 722 (2000) (allowing an appellate court to affirm on any ground in the record).Â  Therefore, Alford cannot maintain this action against Tamsberg because he is a future successor of Belmont Hosiery, and she agreed to forgo any future suit based on the disputed marshlands in exchange for forty acres.Â 
 
IV.Â  Motion For a New Trial
Alford argues the master erred in denying her motion for a new trial based on newly discovered evidence.Â  We disagree.
The grant or refusal of a new trial lies within the discretion of the trial court.Â 
Gray v. Bryant, 298 S.C. 285, 288, 379 S.E.2d 894, 896 (1989) (citing 
Jenkins v. Dixie Specialty Co., Inc., 284 S.C. 425, 326 S.E.2d 658 (1985)). Â In order to grant a new trial based upon the ground of newly discovered evidence a party must show: 



	(1) that the evidence is such as will probably change the result, if a new trial is granted. (2) That it has been discovered since the trial. (3) That it could not have been discovered before the trial by the exercise of due diligence. (4) That it is material to the issue. (5) That it is not merely cumulative or impeaching . . . . 
	

Evatt v. Campbell, 234 S.C. 1, 11-12,106 S.E.2d 447, 453 (1959) (citations omitted).Â  
 
In the present case, Alfordâ€™s newly discovered evidence consists of Â deeds from the 18th century, discovered subsequent to trial, that caused her to question the placement of the Butler Grant in relation to her land.Â  She contends the placement of the Butler Grant has a significant bearing on the boundary line between her and Tamsbergâ€™s property.Â  Although we appreciate the difficulty of drudging through old records and acknowledge that Alfordâ€™s task has not been easy, we find because the evidence could have been found, with due diligence, prior to the trial, it does not constitute newly discovered evidence.Â  Further, Alford has not shown how the newly discovered evidence would change the result of this case.Â  Regardless of what these new deeds reveal, we cannot conceive of a way in which they would change the fact Tamsbergâ€™s title to the marshlands is valid under the twenty year grant theory and the forty-year lapse statute.Â  Accordingly, we find the master properly denied Alfordâ€™s motion for a new trial.
V.Â  Trespass
Alford argues the master erred in dismissing her claim for trespass. She contends because she is the title owner to the marshlands, Tamsberg has trespassed upon her property.Â  For the reasons stated above, we find Tamsberg is the rightful owner of the marshlands, and, therefore, no claim of trespass can lie against him.Â  Accordingly, we find the master properly dismissed Alfordâ€™s claim.
CONCLUSION
We find the master properly concluded the boundary line to the highland portion between Alfordâ€™s and Tamsbergâ€™s adjoining properties is the center of the ditch.Â  We also find Tamsberg has established possession of a fee interest in the marshlands under the twenty year grant theory and the forty-year lapse statute.Â  Accordingly, the order of the master is 
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.
