THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Eddie Wayne Eldridge, Charles Louis Beaudrot, Russie Beaudrot Young, Bernard H. Padgett, Homer Charles Walker, and Ray F. Stewart, individually, and on behalf of a class of plaintiffs similarly situated, and Herbert Malcolm Crum, individually, and on behalf of a class of plaintiffs similarly situated, Appellants/Respondents.
				v.
				SC Department of Transportation, Respondent/Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenwood County
Honorable Robert M. Erwin, Jr., Special Referee

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-351
Heard February 7, 2007 â€“ Filed July 11, 2007Â Â  

AFFIRMEDÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  


	
		
			
				J. Kendall Few, of Greer and Thomas E Hite, Jr., of Abbeville, for Appellants-Respondents.
				George P. Callison, Jr. of Greenwood, for Respondent-Appellant.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  This action was originally filed in 1986 concerning the former right-of-way owned by Southern Railway in and near the City of Greenwood.Â  The plaintiffs (hereinafter referred to as â€œthe property ownersâ€) brought suit seeking a declaratory judgment as to the abandonment and ownership of the right-of-way, to quiet title, and to determine damages for the taking of the abandoned right-of-way.Â  The first two actions were previously decided, and this cross-appeal involves only the determination of damages by the Special Referee for the taking of property by the South Carolina Department of Transportation (SCDOT).Â  We affirm.
FACTS[1]
The property owners sought damages related to two projects initiated by SCDOT in the former right-of-way abandoned by Southern Railway.Â  The first project (the 1986 project) consisted of two main areas: 1) the portion of the right-of-way which currently is situated between two existing roadways (Property Between The Roads); and 2) property directly adjacent to the existing landowners (Adjacent Property).Â  The second project (Calhoun Road Project) consisted of eighteen tracts located within the abandoned right-of-way along Calhoun Road.Â  The property owners consisted of two classes:Â  the current property owners along the right-of-way, and the heirs of the original landowners at the time the right-of-way was acquired by the railroad.
Prior to trial, the parties stipulated to the number of square feet involved in the projects, the certification of the class, the interest rate to be charged, and the division among former and current property owners.Â  A hearing was held before the special referee and both sides presented expert testimony regarding the value of the property taken by SCDOT.
During the hearing, the property ownersâ€™ appraiser concurred in the valuation established by SCDOTâ€™s appraiser for the adjacent property.Â  The Adjacent Property was valued at $3.50 per square foot.Â  The property ownersâ€™ appraiser then testified the Property Between The Roads should be reduced by no more than fifty percent of the value of the Adjacent Property.Â  In other words, he testified the Property Between The Roads should be valued at no less than $1.75 per square foot.
The property ownersâ€™ appraiser also testified regarding the valuations established for the Calhoun Road Project.Â  He testified the values used by SCDOT for the residential properties were accurate and fair.Â  However, he believed the values for commercial property were understated.Â  He testified that when looking at zoning classifications, some commercial property sold for $4.25 per square foot, while property in a prime location sold for $8.50 per square foot. Â He admitted he did not perform an individual appraisal of each property to be considered for valuation.Â  Instead, he stated he looked at the general location and the zoning classification and derived his value based on those general classifications.Â  Finally, the property ownersâ€™ appraiser admitted it would be much more desirable to do an individual appraisal on each property instead of the mass appraisal based on zoning classification. 
 
In regards to the Property Between The Roads, the property ownersâ€™ appraiser admitted no buildings could be built on the property, but suggested it could be beautified and used for signs to attract attention to the businesses across the street.Â  However, he admitted he did not know whether or not a sign could be placed on the Property Between The Roads due to Greenwood County ordinances.
SCDOTâ€™s appraiser testified in detail regarding his method for analyzing and valuing the individual properties.Â  He stated that the Property Between The Roads had no economic value to the landowners.Â  He stated that based on his understanding, no signs could be erected on the property, and it could not be used for anything to generate value.Â  The appraiser stated the owners only had liabilities associated with owning the property.
Additionally, SCDOTâ€™s appraiser testified regarding his appraisal of the individual properties in the Calhoun Road Project.Â  In contrast to the property ownersâ€™ appraiser, SCDOTâ€™s appraiser compared each property based on previous sales instead of just considering them based on their zoning.Â  His analysis showed values ranging from approximately $1.21 per square foot to $2.77 per square foot.
After the hearing, the ordinances relevant to the issue of whether a sign may be erected on the Property Between The Roads were entered into evidence, and each side was able to submit letters regarding the application of the ordinances.Â  The ordinance sets forth specific requirements for â€œpermanent on premises identification signs for which a permit is required.â€
The referee ruled the Property Between The Roads could not house signs because they were not on the same premises owned by the landowners, were not adjoining or contingent to the property on which the business was located, and were not on property with the same ownership as the property on which the businesses were located.Â  As a result, the referee found no compensation was required for the Property Between The Roads.Â  The court also found the Adjacent Property should be valued at a total of $198,278.63.
Finally, the court set forth the values of the individual properties involved in the condemnation for the Calhoun Road Project.Â  The court utilized the values set forth by SCDOTâ€™s appraiser for all of the properties except the commercial properties.Â  For the commercial properties, the court found a value between that offered by SCDOT and the value proposed by the property ownersâ€™ appraiser.Â  The commercial property values ranged from $2.00 to $5.00.Â  Neither party filed a motion to alter or amend the judgment pursuant to Rule 59, SCRCP.Â  This cross-appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An action to recover damages resulting from the condemnation of property is an action at law.Â  See South Carolina Pub. Serv. Auth. v. Arnold,Â  287 S.C. 584, 586, 340 S.E.2d 535, 537 (1986).Â  In an action at law, tried by a judge without a jury, the findings of the trial court must be affirmed if there is any evidence to reasonably support them.Â  Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Property Ownersâ€™ Appeal
The property owners raise two main arguments: 1) the referee incorrectly ruled the Property Between The Roads could not be used for the purpose of erecting identification signs; and 2) the referee failed to establish some value for the Property Between the Roads.Â  We disagree.
A.  Signs
The property owners maintain the Property Between The Roads was â€œon the premisesâ€ of their businesses because it was either adjacent to or conjoining their property.Â  As a result, they argue the Property Between The Roads is available for their use to place identification signs and the Greenwood County ordinance would not prohibit the erection of signs on the property.Â  We disagree.

	The Greenwood County ordinance states:
	
		(d) Permanent on premises identification signs for which a permit is required:Â  One (1) free-standing identification sign 
		per lot for each 100 feet, or fraction thereof of street frontage over 200 feet, provided said signs shall . . . be located no closer than 5 feet from the nearest property line.Â  
		
	

(Emphasis added).
Regulations covering similar â€œon premisesâ€ signs define the term to mean:Â  â€œany sign which is designed, intended or used to advertise or inform of the principal activity taking place, or the product being sold on the property where the sign is located.â€Â  25A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 63-342 (Q) (Supp. 2006).Â 
 
The term â€œon premisesâ€ in the Greenwood County ordinance also requires the sign be placed on the same lot as the entity being advertised.Â  In this case, we must determine whether the Property Between The Roads is the same lot as the land upon which the property owners have entities they wish to advertise.
The order of Judge Macaulay from 1996, which is the subject of Eldridge II, states:Â  â€œAs to that portion of the former right-of-way covered by streets, highways, and sidewalks for more than 20 years prior to the filing of the Complaint in this case on October 1, 1986, the title lies in the City, County, and Highway Department.â€Â  Â Judge Macaulay continued:

	Upon extinguishment of the easement, for that portion of the former Railroad right-of-way which has 
	not been covered by streets, highways, sidewalks, or other roadway improvements for a period of 20 years prior to the filing of this suit in 1986 . . . the unencumbered fee resides in the original property owners at the time of acquisition of these rights-of-way by the Railroad or the adjacent property owners at the time of the abandonment of the Railroad right-of-way in January 1985, which issue is left for future determination.Â  
	

(Emphasis added).Â  These rulings by Judge Macaulay were not appealed by either party.Â  Accordingly, they have become the law of the case.Â  See Charleston Lumber Co. v. Miller Housing Corp., 338 S.C. 171, 175, 525 S.E.2d 869, 871 (2000) (unappealed ruling, right or wrong, is the law of the case).Â  Additionally, Judge Curetonâ€™s opinion in Eldridge II noted:Â  â€œThe [order by Judge Macaulay] made rulings relative to the [SCDOTâ€™s] adverse possession of portions of the corridor, as well as to the [SCDOTâ€™s] independent acquisition of rights of way from adjoining property owners.â€Â  Eldridge II, 331 S.C. 398, 436, 503 S.E.2d 191, 211 (Ct. App. 1998).
Based on the above unappealed rulings by Judge Macaulay, SCDOT owns the portion of the land upon which the roads are situated.Â  Therefore, the Property Between The Roads is physically separated from the property ownersâ€™ other property by the roads.Â  Accordingly, the Property Between The Roads is not contiguous, adjacent, or adjoining the property ownersâ€™ other property upon which the business entity is situated.Â  See e.g., Young v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Hwys and Pub. Transp., 287 S.C. 108, 110 n. 1, 336 S.E.2d 879, 880 n. 1 (Ct. App. 1985) (stating on premise signs are located â€œcontiguous with the land occupied by the commercial or industrial activity.â€). Â Concomitantly, the on premises sign ordinance would not allow a sign identifying the property ownersâ€™ business or other entity to be placed on the Property Between The Roads.Â  Accordingly, we find the referee correctly determined the Property Between The Roads could not be used for identification signs.
B.  Value of Property
The property owners contend the Property Between The Roads should have value because they could place signs on the property or, in the alternative, because it could be used for some purpose such as a parking space or a biking trail.Â  The property owners, therefore, assert some value should have been assigned to the property for purposes of the condemnation.Â 
 
The property owners fail to cite any supporting authority for the position, and all arguments made are merely conclusory statements.Â  As such, the property owners have abandoned the issue on appeal and it need not be addressed by this court.Â  See First Sav. Bank v. McLean, 314 S.C. 361, 363, 444 S.E.2d 513, 514 (1994).
II.  SCDOTâ€™s Appeal
SCDOT maintains the referee erred in not accepting SCDOTâ€™s appraiserâ€™s value for the commercial property condemned in the Calhoun Road Project because there was no other valid evidence presented in the record.Â  We disagree.
First, we note this issue is not preserved for review on appeal.Â  SCDOT is challenging the evidence presented in its issue on appeal.Â  However, the issue was never raised to the referee for his consideration.Â  SCDOT should have made a motion to alter or amend pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€) (citation omitted).
Even if the issue were properly raised to the referee, there is evidence in the record supporting the refereeâ€™s valuation.Â  The property ownersâ€™ appraiser testified that the property was worth between $4.25 and $8.50.Â  SCDOTâ€™s appraiser valued the property between $1.21 and $2.77.Â  The courtâ€™s valuation placed a value on the property between $2.00 and $5.00.Â  Based on our standard of review, we find the range offered by the parties presents evidence supporting the refereeâ€™s conclusion that the value of the commercial properties fell within that range.
CONCLUSION
We hold the referee correctly determined the Property Between The Roads could not be the site of identification signs used by the property owners due to the restrictions in the Greenwood County Ordinances.Â  We conclude, due to a failure to cite any supporting authority, the property owners have abandoned the issue which alleged error in finding the Property Between The Roads had no value for compensation purposes.Â  Finally, we determine the valuation placed on the commercial property condemned in the Calhoun Road Project was appropriate.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the referee is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, KITTREDGE, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] For a thorough discussion of the background of this action refer to Eldridge v. City of Greenwood, 300 S.C. 369, 388 S.E.2d 247 (Ct. App. 1989), and Eldridge v. City of Greenwood, 331 S.C. 398, 503 S.E.2d 191 (Ct. App. 1998) (Eldridge II).

title: DSS v. Crystal S.
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Department of Social Services, Respondent,
				v.
				Crystal S., Lynette B., and Victor F., Defendants, of whom Victor F. is Appellant.
				In the interest of: Theresa S.[1] (Born 5/25/02); Minor child under the age of 18.
			
		
	


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â Georgia V. Anderson, Family Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2007-UP-353
Submitted July 2, 2007 â€“ Filed July 12, 2007
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED
Â 


	
		
			
				William Cory Hughes, of Greenville, for Appellant.
				Deborah Murdock, of Greenville, for Respondent.
				Hattie Darlene Evans Boyce, of Spartanburg, Guardian Ad Litem.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Â In this family court action, Victor F. (Father) appeals the family courtâ€™s order removing Theresa S. (Child) from his custody.Â  Father argues the family court should not have removed Child because it did not find that he abused or neglected her.Â  Father further argues the family court did not comply with the statutory requirements that mandate the Department of Social Services (DSS) make reasonable efforts to prevent Childâ€™s removal.Â  Fatherâ€™s final argument is the family court failed to consider the appropriate factors in determining removal was in Childâ€™s best interests.Â  We affirm as modified.
FACTS
This case commenced on April 1, 2006, when Crystal S. (Mother),[2] a minor child of age 17, entered the custody of DSS upon accusations of inappropriately touching a five-year-old male.Â  Thereafter, DSS learned Mother had a three-year-old daughter who at that time was living with her paternal great grandmother, Lynette B. (Great Grandmother).[3]Â  At a hearing on April 3, 2006, the family court ordered DSS to investigate Childâ€™s living environment at Great Grandmotherâ€™s home.Â  DSS visited the home the next day, and Great Grandmother informed DSS that Father also lived in her home, but he was not present at the time.Â  Later, DSS also learned that Great Grandmotherâ€™s home had an extensive history with law enforcement.Â  Due to the conditions of the home, the court entered an ex parte order on April 17, 2006, ordering Child to enter DSS custody.Â 
 
On April 18, 2006, DSS initiated an action seeking removal of Child from Great Grandmotherâ€™s home on the grounds that Mother, Father, and Great Grandmother abused and/or neglected Child.Â  Following the probable cause hearing, the court ordered Child to be placed in emergency protective custody with DSS because (1) probable cause existed to believe Child had been neglected or abused, (2) DSS exercised reasonable efforts to prevent Childâ€™s removal, and (3) continuation in Great Grandmotherâ€™s home was not in Childâ€™s best interests.Â 
 
The family court held the removal hearing on June 22, 2006.[4]Â  On August 2, 2006, the family court found DSS had not established by a preponderance of the evidence that Child was abused or neglected by Father or Great Grandmother.Â  The family court found the home of Father and Great Grandmother was not a suitable environment for Child and returning her to the home would be contrary to her best interests.Â  Further, because Father had no court order determining his paternity as to Child, and Mother and Father were not married, the family court ordered temporary custody of Child to DSS pending the merits hearing in the case against Mother.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In domestic matters, we may find facts based on the preponderance of the evidence, but we are not required to disregard the findings of the family court judge, who was in a better position to evaluate the witnessesâ€™ testimony and credibility.Â  Doe v. Doe, 319 S.C. 151, 155, 459 S.E.2d 892, 894 (Ct. App. 1995).
LAW/ANALYSIS
A. Custody of children born out of wedlock
Before we address Fatherâ€™s arguments, we must determine which parent has custody of Child.Â  Section 20-7-953(B) of the South Carolina Code (1976) provides:

	Unless the court orders otherwise, the custody of an illegitimate child is solely in the natural mother unless the mother has relinquished her rights to the child.Â  If paternity has been acknowledged or adjudicated, the father may petition the court for rights of visitation or custody in a proceeding before the court apart from an action to establish paternity.Â  
	

Neither party disputes that Mother and Father are not married nor that Child was conceived out of wedlock.Â  Based on these facts, the first sentence of the statute would place custody of Child with Mother.Â  The second sentence of the statute allows the Father to petition the court for custody if Father has acknowledged paternity.Â  The following excerpt illustrates Father acknowledged his paternity:

	[Court]:Â  Youâ€™re acknowledging youâ€™re the father?
	[Father]:Â  Yes.
	[Court]:Â  As the Father of this child, you do have an obligation to take care of it [sic] wherever it [sic] is.Â  Iâ€™m going to put you under an order to pay child support. 
	

Father acknowledged paternity, thus the second sentence of section 20-7-953(B) allows him to petition the court for custody.Â  However, the record is devoid of any attempt by Father to seek custody of Child.Â  The following is a passage from the family court proceeding in which DSS investigator Vickie Cook is being questioned by the family court judge:

	[Court]:Â  Okay. And so at this point and time, I guess to your knowledge is there any custody order concerning [Child] other than the D.S.S. order, which took her into protective custody?
	[Cook]:Â  Thatâ€™s the only order.Â  [Great Grandmother] . . . spoke of an attorney and that she was pursuing custody of [Child], but there was no order [regarding Child].

Â The record reveals Father never sought custody of Child.Â  Further, the family court informed Father that he had a right to seek custody of Child.Â  Consequently, Father does not have custody of Child. 
 
B. Removal based on abuse or neglect
Father argues the family court erred in granting temporary legal and physical custody of Child to DSS because it did not comply with sections 20-736(F) and (I) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006).Â  Subsection (F) states the family court:

	shall not order that a child be removed from the custody of the parent or guardian unless the court finds that the allegations of the petition[5] are supported by a preponderance of evidence including a finding that the child is an abused or neglected child . . . Â and that retention of the child in or return of the Â child to the home would place the child at unreasonable risk of harm affecting the childâ€™s life, physical health or safety, or mental well-being and the child cannot reasonably be protected from this harm without being removed. 
	

(emphasis added).
The statute applies only if Child is in Fatherâ€™s custody.Â  As explained above, Father did not have custody of Child nor has Father sought custody.Â  Moreover, the case against Mother is pending.Â  Thus, section 20-7-736(F) is inapplicable.Â  
 

	Section 20-7-736(I) states: 
	If the court removes custody of the child, the courtâ€™s order shall contain a finding by the court of whether reasonable efforts were made by the department to prevent removal of the child and a finding of whether continuation of the child in the home would be contrary to the welfare of the child.Â  The order shall state: (1) the services made available to the family before the removal of the child and how they related to the needs of the family; (2) the efforts of the agency to provide these services to the family before removal; (3) why the efforts to provide services did not eliminate the need for removal; and (4) whether the efforts to eliminate the need for removal were reasonable. . . .Â  If the departmentâ€™s first contact with the child occurred under such circumstances that reasonable services would not have allowed the child to remain safely in the home, the court shall find that removal of the child without services or without further services was reasonable.Â  
	

(emphasis added).
Once again, the statute applies only if Child is in Fatherâ€™s custody.Â  As explained above, Father did not have custody of Child.Â  Thus, section 20-7-736(I) is inapplicable.Â  Additionally, given the fact that DSS took Child into protective custody pursuant to an ex parte order, this would not allow DSS sufficient time to provide services.Â  Therefore, under the circumstances, the efforts made by DSS to prevent removal were reasonable.Â Â 
 
C. The Moore[6] factors 
Father contends the family court erred because it failed to consider the Moore factors in determining that removal was in the best interests of Child.Â  Specifically, Father argues absent a finding that Child was abused or neglected or that Father is an unfit parent, the family court erred in concluding removal was in Childâ€™s best interests.
Our courts have typically used the Moore factors in actions in which a natural parent seeks to regain custody of a child after the parent has voluntarily surrendered custody of a child to a third person.Â  Charleston County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. King, 369 S.C. 96, 102, 631 S.E.2d 239, 242 (2006); Dodge v. Dodge, 332 S.C. 401, 411, 505 S.E.2d 344, 349 (Ct. App. 1998) (â€œIn Moore, the supreme court outlined the criteria to consider in determining custody when a natural parent seeks to reclaim custody from a third party.â€).Â  
 
However, in the present case, neither Father nor Mother voluntarily relinquished custody of Child.Â  Rather, the court ordered Child to be placed in emergency protective custody when DSS investigated Childâ€™s living environment, and the lower court found probable cause to remove Child from Father and Great Grandmotherâ€™s home.Â  Thus, the Moore factors do not apply in the circumstances of the present case.Â  Accordingly, the family court did not err in failing to consider the Moore factors in its determination of Childâ€™s removal from the home.
â€œ[T]he welfare of the child and what is in his/her best interest is the primary, paramount and controlling consideration of the court in all child custody controversies.â€Â  Davis v. Davis, 356 S.C. 132, 135, 588 S.E.2d 102, 103-04 (2003) (internal citations and quotations omitted).Â  Father and Great Grandmother are the two named defendants.Â  The case against Mother is pending.Â  The issue of neglect, with respect to Mother, has not been fully litigated.Â  We hold it is in Childâ€™s best interests to remain in the custody of DSS while the case against Mother is resolved.Â  See Ex Parte Morris, 367 S.C. 56, 61-62, 624 S.E.2d 649, 652 (2006) (In an appeal from a family court order, an appellate court is not required to disregard the findings of the family court judge.Â  This degree of deference is especially true in cases involving a childâ€™s welfare and best interests.). 
 
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, the lower courtâ€™s decision is  
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED.[7]Â  

STILWELL, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] The names of the minor child and the defendants have been changed to protect the minorâ€™s identity. 
 
[2] Mother is not a party to this appeal. 
 
[3] Great Grandmother is not a party to this appeal. 
 
[4] On June 22, 2006, the family court heard the matter only as to Father and Great Grandmother.Â  The case was continued as to Mother because her court-appointed attorney was absent from the hearing.Â  Â 
[5] Section 20-7-736(B) states DSS â€œmay petition the family court to remove the child from custody of the parent, guardian, or other person legally responsible for the childâ€™s welfare if [DSS] determines by a preponderance of evidence that the child is an abused or neglected child and that the child cannot be safely maintained in the home in that he cannot be protected from unreasonable risk of harm affecting the childâ€™s life, physical health, safety, or mental well-being without removal.â€Â Â Â 
 
[6] In Moore v. Moore, our Supreme Court established the following criteria to consider in making custody determinations when a parent seeks to reclaim custody: (1) the parent must prove that he or she is a fit parent, able to properly care for the child and provide a good home; (2) the amount of contact, in the form of visits, financial support or both, which the parent had with the child while it was in the care of the third party; (3) the circumstances under which temporary relinquishment occurred; and (4) the degree of attachment between the child and the temporary custodian.Â  300 S.C. 75, 79-80, 386 S.E.2d 456, 458 (1989).
[7] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Lois Burris Brunson, Appellant/Respondent,
				v.
				Dennis Dean Brunson, Respondent/Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From York County
Â Georgia V. Anderson, Family Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-354
Submitted May 1, 2007 â€“ Filed July 16, 2007
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED 



	
		
			
				Thomas F. McDow, of Rock Hill, for Appellant/Respondent.
				David C. Shea and John S. Nichols, both of Columbia, for Respondent/Appellant.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  In this domestic action, Lois Brunson (Wife) and Dennis Brunson (Husband) appeal the family courtâ€™s order.Â  Both parties assign numerous points of error, including the award of alimony, the equitable distribution of the marital assets, and the failure to award attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.
FACTS
Wife and Husband married on March 9, 1986 and separated on October 18, 2002.Â  Both parties had children from their previous marriages, but they had no children from their marriage.Â  Wife brought a home into the marriage worth approximately $70,000 at the time they married, which had a mortgage of approximately $32,000.Â  Wife also had a retirement account worth $12,000 at the time of the marriage.Â  In 1993, when the account was worth $25,000, Wife withdrew the funds with Husbandâ€™s knowledge and spent them on the family and improvements to the marital home.Â  In 1998, with Wifeâ€™s knowledge, Husband opened a â€œblow account,â€ into which he deposited funds for his personal use. 
 
During the marriage, Wife worked as manager of a credit union and earned approximately $34,000 per year.Â  During her employment, Wife used Husbandâ€™s and her daughterâ€™s name to secure several loans and obtained additional funds on already existing loans in their names.Â  Much of the loan proceeds were used to finance a ski boat, a vehicle, a tractor, family vacations, to pay off credit cards, and for other family purposes.Â  When the credit union learned of Wifeâ€™s actions, she was fired.Â  
 
In September 2003, Wife pled guilty, pursuant to a negotiated plea, to twelve charges of forgery, four charges of bank fraud, and one charge of breach of trust.Â  Wife received concurrent sentences amounting to a ten-year sentence suspended upon five years probation.Â  Prior to her guilty plea, she paid $30,000 in restitution, and at the time of the divorce decree, she still owed approximately $26,000 in restitution as well as $4,250 in fees. Â 
Wife is currently employed at a salon and spa and has gross earnings of $1,163.72 per month and net earnings of $923.74.Â  Husband continues to work at Duke Power. Â He has gross monthly earnings of $5,339, and after taxes and insurance premiums, he has net earnings of $3,045. Â He also receives mileage income and a yearly bonus.Â  Wife settled a personal injury lawsuit for $32,500 prior to attorneyâ€™s fees and medical bills, but at the commencement of litigation, Wife had yet to receive the proceeds.Â  Husband received a workersâ€™ compensation settlement for $108,000 following the partiesâ€™ separation.Â  
 
On November 2, 2002, Wife filed a complaint requesting alimony, separate maintenance and support, equitable apportionment of the marital property, attorneyâ€™s fees, and pendente lite relief.Â  On December 11, 2002, the family court issued a temporary order declining to award alimony pendente lite.Â  Further, the family court determined Husband would retain the use of the marital home but ordered him to pay Wife $300 per month as an unspecified advance for the use of her interest in the home.Â 
 
Husband remained in the marital home until the summer of 2003, when he moved in with his girlfriend in North Carolina.Â  In June 2004, Husband bought a home in North Carolina.Â  Husbandâ€™s son continued to reside in the marital home.Â  Wife has lived with her mother since the partiesâ€™ separation.Â  On November 20, 2003, Wife filed a supplemental complaint requesting a divorce on the grounds of adultery and one yearâ€™s continuous separation.Â  

On February 9, 2005, the family court granted the parties a divorce based on one yearâ€™s continuous separation.Â  The family court awarded sixty percent of the marital estate to Husband and forty percent to Wife. Â The family court ordered the parties to sell the marital home, but it found Wife had a special equity of $35,000 in the home.Â  Additionally, the family court found each party should retain all of their respective personal injury awards.Â  The remainder of the marital estate was valued at $21,195, although $2,100 of that value was debt.Â  

Additionally, the family court classified the $300 monthly payment to Wife as alimony.Â  The family court found Wife was entitled to continue receiving alimony until December 2005, explaining the award was both rehabilitative and lump sum and would enable her to maintain some stability during the next year while the property division was being accomplished and would also help her maintain health insurance.Â  In addition, the family court determined each party should be responsible for their respective attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Wife filed a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion for reconsideration, and the family court reaffirmed its order, making minor modifications.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal from a family court order, this Court has authority to correct errors of law and find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  
E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 473, 415 S.E.2d 812, 814 (1992).Â  When reviewing decisions of the family court, we are cognizant of the fact that the family court had the opportunity to see the witnesses, hear â€œthe testimony delivered from the stand, and had the benefit of that personal observance of and contact with the parties which is of peculiar value in arriving at a correct result in a case of this character.â€Â  DuBose v. DuBose, 259 S.C. 418, 423, 192 S.E.2d 329, 331 (1972) (internal quotations omitted). Â When the evidence is conflicting and susceptible of different inferences, the family court has the duty of determining not only the law of the case, but the facts as well.Â  Anders v. Anders, 285 S.C. 512, 514, 331 S.E.2d 340, 341 (1985); see also Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996) (holding when evidence is disputed, the appellate court may adhere to the family courtâ€™s findings).Â  
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Alimony
Wife contends the family court erred in awarding rehabilitative and lump sum alimony rather than permanent periodic alimony because the family court failed to make findings of special circumstances.Â  Wife further argues the family court erred in awarding alimony of only $300 per month. Â Husband contends the family court erred in awarding Wife any alimony.Â  
 
The amount of alimony, as well as a determination of whether the spouse is entitled to alimony, is within the sound discretion of the family court.Â  Smith v. Smith, 264 S.C. 624, 628, 216 S.E.2d 541, 543 (1975).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the decision is controlled by an error of law or is based on factual findings that are without evidentiary support.Â  
Degenhart v. Burriss, 360 S.C. 497, 500, 602 S.E.2d 96, 97 (Ct. App. 2004). Â 
The purpose of alimony is to place the supported spouse, as close as is practical, in the same position of support as during the marriage.Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 300, 372 S.E.2d 107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988). Â If the claim for alimony is well-founded, the family court has the duty of making â€œan alimony award that is fit, equitable, and just.â€Â  Allen v. Allen, 347 S.C. 177, 184, 554 S.E.2d 421, 424 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  The family court should consider the following factors in awarding alimony: 
 

	(1) duration of the marriage; (2) physical and emotional health of the parties; (3) educational background of the parties; (4) employment history and earning potential of the parties; (5) standard of living established during the marriage; (6) current and reasonably anticipated earnings of the parties; (7) current and reasonably anticipated expenses of the parties; (8) marital and nonmarital properties of the parties; (9) custody of children; (10) marital misconduct or fault; (11) tax consequences; and (12) prior support obligations; as well as (13) other factors the court considers relevant.

Id. (citing S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C) (Supp. 2000)).Â  
 
The South Carolina Supreme Court has further held that â€œ[t]hree important factors in awarding periodic alimony are (1) the duration of the marriage; (2) the overall financial situation of the parties, especially the ability of the supporting spouse to pay; and (3) whether either spouse was more at fault than the other.â€Â  Patel v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 529, 599 S.E.2d 114, 121 (2004).Â  
 
The family court may grant alimony and separate maintenance and support awards pendente lite and permanently in amounts and for lengths of time that the family court considers appropriate under the circumstances.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(B) (Supp. 2006).Â  These awards may include: â€œ(1) periodic alimony . . . (2) lump-sum alimony . . . (3) rehabilitative alimony . . . (4) reimbursement alimony . . . (5) separate maintenance and support . . . [and] (6) [s]uch other form of spousal support, under terms and conditions as the court may consider just, as appropriate under the circumstances without limitation to grant more than one form of support.â€Â  Id.Â  
 
Â Section 20-3-130(B)(2) describes lump sum alimony as â€œa finite total sum to be paid in one installment, or periodically over a period of time, terminating only upon the death of the supported spouse, but not terminable or modifiable based upon remarriage or changed circumstances in the future.â€ Â The statute further provides the purpose of lump sum alimony may include, but not be limited to, circumstances in which the family court finds alimony appropriate but determines that the award be finite and nonmodifiable.Â  Id.Â Â Â Â  To grant lump sum alimony, the court must find special circumstances that would make any award of lump sum alimony advisable.Â  Atkinson v. Atkinson, 279 S.C. 454, 456-57, 309 S.E.2d 14, 15 (Ct. App. 1983).Â  
 
Typically, the primary justification in awarding lump sum alimony is the unreliability of the supporting spouse to make regular payments.Â  See Roy T. Stuckey, Marital Litigation in South Carolina 217 (3d ed. 2001); see also Jones v. Jones, 270 S.C. 280, 282, 241 S.E.2d 904, 905 (1978) (upholding the award of $36,000 in lump sum alimony when husband drank excessively, was not regularly employed, had failed to pay child support for the last five years, threatened to leave the country to avoid payments, and had just inherited property valued near $100,000); Murdock v. Murdock,243 S.C. 218, 225, 133 S.E.2d 323, 326 (1963) (affirming lump sum alimony of $4,250 when the husband moved to a distant state, remarried, and had been found in contempt of court for failing to pay pendente lite alimony); Hendricks v. Hendricks,285 S.C. 591, 594, 330 S.E.2d 553, 554 (Ct. App. 1985) (affirming lump sum alimony of $30,000 when husband failed to support his family for nineteen years and quickly spent a $45,000 inheritance by purchasing a truck and by paying the hospital bills of a paramour in another state).Â  
 
On the other hand, section 20-3-130(B)(3) defines rehabilitative alimony as follows:

	[A] finite sum to be paid in one installment or periodically, terminable upon the remarriage or continued cohabitation of the supported spouse, the death of either spouse . . . or the occurrence of a specific event to occur in the future, or modifiable based upon unforeseen events frustrating the good faith efforts of the supported spouse to become self-supporting or the ability of the supporting spouse to pay the rehabilitative alimony.Â  
	

The purpose of rehabilitative alimony may include, but is not limited to, circumstances in which the family court finds providing for the rehabilitation of the supported spouse appropriate.Â  Id.; see also Eagerton v. Eagerton, 285 S.C. 279, 282, 328 S.E.2d 912, 914 (Ct. App. 1985) (â€œThe purpose of rehabilitative alimony is to encourage a dependent spouse to become self-supporting by providing alimony for a limited period of time during which the dependent spouse might retrain and rehabilitate himself or herself thereby limiting the duration of the time in which the supporting spouse is burdened by spousal support.â€). Â Moreover, rehabilitative alimony permits a couple to develop their own lives free from obligations to each other. Â Id., 328 S.E.2d at 914-15.Â  For the family court to grant rehabilitative alimony, the evidence must demonstrate the supported spouse will be self-sufficient at the expiration of the ordered payments. Â Toler v. Toler, 292 S.C. 374, 378, 356 S.E.2d 429, 431 (Ct. App. 1987).
In its decision to award lump sum and rehabilitative alimony, the family court stated it was continuing the temporary alimony of $300 per month.Â  However, the $300 per month provided by the temporary order was not temporary alimony but rather an unspecified advance on Wifeâ€™s interest in the home.Â  Further, we find the family court failed to make sufficient findings to support its award of lump sum and rehabilitative alimony.
The family court stated the award was to enable Wife to maintain some stability during the next year while the property division was being accomplished and to help her maintain health insurance.Â  Without further justification, these findings are insufficient to justify either lump sum or rehabilitative alimony.Â  
 
Consequently, the insufficiency of the record before this Court requires us to remand this case to the family court to determine whether an alimony award is appropriate.Â  On remand, if the family court wishes to award alimony, it must make specific findings in the order to support the award.Â  
 
Further, alimony is intended to be neither a reward nor a punishment. Â Kane v. Kane, 280 S.C. 479, 484, 313 S.E.2d 327, 330 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  The purpose of alimony is to maintain as near as possible the status quo established by the parties during the marriage.Â  Id.Â  In determining whether to award alimony and what amount and type of alimony to award, â€œ[A]ll of the facts and circumstances disclosed by the record should be considered; no one factor should be determined dispositive.â€Â  Nienow v. Nienow, 268 S.C. 161, 171, 232 S.E.2d 504, 510 (1977). Â 
Based on these considerations, we leave it to the family courtâ€™s discretion to take into account all of the relevant factors in determining whether alimony is appropriate, and if it is, in deciding what type and what amount should be awarded.Â 
 
II.Â  Equitable Distribution
A.Â  Overall Distribution
Both Husband and Wife maintain the family court erred in awarding a sixty-forty division of marital property in favor of Husband.Â  We disagree.
The division of marital property is within the family courtâ€™s sound discretion, and this decision will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion. Â Craig v. Craig, 365 S.C. 285, 290, 617 S.E.2d 359, 361 (2005).Â  The appellate court looks to the overall fairness of the apportionment. Â Deidun v. Deidun, 362 S.C. 47, 58, 606 S.E.2d 489, 495 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  If the end result is equitable, the fact that the appellate court would have arrived at a different apportionment is irrelevant. Â Id. Â â€œThe doctrine of equitable distribution is based on a recognition that marriage is, among other things, an economic partnership.â€ Â Mallett v. Mallett, 323 S.C. 141, 150, 473 S.E.2d 804, 810 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  â€œUpon dissolution of the marriage, property acquired during the marriage should be divided and distributed in a manner which fairly reflects each spouseâ€™s contribution to its acquisition, regardless of which spouse holds legal title.â€Â  Id.
In making an equitable apportionment of marital property, the family court must proportionately weigh the following factors:

	Â (1) the duration of the marriage together with the ages of the parties at the time of the marriage and at the time of the divorce or separate maintenance or other marital action between the parties; (2) marital misconduct or fault of either or both parties, whether or not used as a basis for a divorce as such, if the misconduct affects or has affected the economic circumstances of the parties, or contributed to the breakup of the marriage; provided, that no evidence of personal conduct which would otherwise be relevant and material for purposes of this subsection shall be considered with regard to this subsection if such conduct shall have taken place subsequent to the happening of the earliest of (a) entry of a pendente lite order in a divorce or separate maintenance action; (b) formal signing of a written property or marital settlement agreement; or (c) entry of a permanent order of separate maintenance and support or of a permanent order approving a property or marital settlement agreement between the parties; (3) the value of the marital property, whether the property be within or without the State. The contribution of each spouse to the acquisition, preservation, depreciation, or appreciation in value of the marital property, including the contribution of the spouse as homemaker; provided, that the court shall consider the quality of the contribution as well as its factual existence; (4) the income of each spouse, the earning potential of each spouse, and the opportunity for future acquisition of capital assets; (5) the health, both physical and emotional, of each spouse; (6) the need of each spouse or either spouse for additional training or education in order to achieve that spousesâ€™s income potential; (7) the nonmarital property of each spouse; (8) the existence or nonexistence of vested retirement benefits for each or either spouse; (9) whether separate maintenance or alimony has been awarded; (10) the desirability of awarding the family home as part of equitable distribution or the right to live therein for reasonable periods to the spouse having custody of any children; (11) the tax consequences to each or either party as a result of any particular form of equitable apportionment; (12) the existence and extent of any support obligations, from a prior marriage or for any other reason or reasons, of either party; (13) liens and any other encumbrances upon the marital property, which themselves must be equitably divided, or upon the separate property of either of the parties, and any other existing debts incurred by the parties or either of them during the course of the marriage; (14) child custody arrangements and obligations at the time of the entry of the order; and (15) such other relevant factors as the trial court shall expressly enumerate in its order.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472 (Supp. 2006).Â   
These criteria are intended to guide the family court in exercising its discretion over apportionment of the marital property. Â Johnson, 296 S.C. at 297, 372 S.E.2d at 112.Â  They are only equities to be considered in reaching a fair distribution of marital property. Â Id. at 297-98, 372 S.E.2d at 112.Â  
 
The ultimate goal of apportionment is both to divide the marital estate, as a whole, in a manner which fairly reflects each spouseâ€™s contribution to the economic partnership and to have the relative effect of ending that partnership on each of the parties.Â  Johnson, 296 S.C. at 298, 372 S.E.2d at 112.
Awards such as the instant case have been previously upheld by this Court.Â  In Brandi v. Brandi, the marriage lasted ten years, the parties were approximately the same age, the husband was in better health, husbandâ€™s adultery caused the breakup of the marriage, the husband demonstrated a greater earning capacity, the husband had far greater nonmarital assets, and he made most of the direct contributions to the acquisition of the marital property.Â  302 S.C. 353, 357, 396 S.E.2d 124, 126 (Ct. App. 1990).Â  The wifeâ€™s contributions, on the other hand, were primarily indirect contributions as a homemaker.Â  Id.Â  The family court awarded the husband seventy percent of the marital property.Â  Id. at 356, 396 S.E.2d at 125.Â  This Court found the award to the wife was most liberal but was not an abuse of discretion.Â  Id. at 358, 396 S.E.2d at 127.Â  
 
Precedent supports similar divisions based on this Stateâ€™s current equitable distribution regime.Â  See Wynn v. Wynn, 360 S.C. 117, 126, 600 S.E.2d 71, 75 (Ct. App. 2004) (modifying family courtâ€™s order to include jointly incurred credit card debt but upholding the family courtâ€™s award of fifty-five percent of the marital estate to the husband following nineteen-year marriage); Pool v. Pool, 321 S.C. 84, 88-89, 467 S.E.2d 753, 756 (Ct. App. 1996) (finding no abuse of discretion when family court awarded sixty percent of marital estate to the husband and forty percent to the wife, wherein marriage lasted three years, the husband made greater direct contributions to marriage, but both parties contributed equally in terms of indirect contributions); Â Sharpe v. Sharpe, 307 S.C. 540, 542, 416 S.E.2d 215, 216 (Ct. App. 1992) (affirming a sixty-five percent division of the marital estate in favor of the husband when parties were married for eighteen years, the husband committed post-separation adultery, and wife conspired to kill husband post-separation); Cross v. Cross, 296 S.C. 474, 475, 374 S.E.2d 178, 178 (1988) (modifying family courtâ€™s order for failure to offset the husbandâ€™s tax payment but upholding its award of eighty-three percent of the marital assets to the wife when parties were married for nine years and the wife made significant non-marital contributions); Coxe v. Coxe, 294 S.C. 291, 294, 363 S.E.2d 906, 908 (Ct. App. 1987) (upholding an award of twenty-five percent of the marital estate to the wife in a marriage that lasted approximately eighteen years, and in which wife could not work outside the home due to a pre-marital disability); Josey v. Josey, 291 S.C. 26, 32, 351 S.E.2d 891, 895 (Ct. App. 1986) (affirming family courtâ€™s award of sixty percent of marital estate to the husband and forty percent to the wife and finding despite husbandâ€™s adultery, the award bore a reasonable relationship to the relative direct and indirect contributions of the parties); Watson v. Watson, 291 S.C. 13, 19-20, 351 S.E.2d 883, 887-88 (Ct. App. 1986) (upholding family courtâ€™s award of thirty-two percent of marital estate to wife after a twenty-three year marriage in which the husbandâ€™s earning potential was vastly superior to that of the wife); Millis v. Millis, 282 S.C. 610, 612-13, 320 S.E.2d 66, 67 (Ct. App. 1984) (finding no abuse of discretion in awarding the wife twenty percent of the marital estate after a fourteen-year marriage).
The equitable distribution of the marital estate is within the sound discretion of the family court, and its decision will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Coxe, 294 S.C. at 295, 363 S.E.2d at 908.Â  Because family court judges are given broad jurisdiction in the equitable distribution of marital property, the family court may use any reasonable means to divide the estate equitably.Â  Id.Â  Accordingly, examining the overall contributions of the parties and the remaining equitable distribution factors, we find the family court did not abuse its discretion in making the distribution.Â  We specifically address some of Husbandâ€™s and Wifeâ€™s assertions of error below.[1]
B.Â  Personal Injury/Workersâ€™ Compensation
Wife asserts the family court erred in apportioning all of Husbandâ€™s proceeds from his workersâ€™ compensation action to Husband because the cause of action occurred before the date of filing and the family court did not make sufficient findings for judicial review.Â  We disagree.
â€œ[P]roceeds of a personal injury settlement acquired during the marriage are marital property subject to the family courtâ€™s jurisdiction.â€Â  Marsh v. Marsh, 313 S.C. 42, 46, 437 S.E.2d 34, 36 (1993).Â  However,

	recognition of the award or settlement as marital property does not mean the proceeds of the award must be divided and a portion awarded to the non-injured spouse. Â To the contrary; the family court may, and in many cases probably should, award the proceeds entirely to the injured spouse. Â We emphasize the family court is not required to divide all marital property between the spouses based on the same percentage of division. Â For example, the court could divide the general marital property equally between the two but award the personal injury compensation entirely to the injured spouse.Â  
	

Id. at 45, 437 S.E.2d at 36 (citations omitted). Â In this case, Husbandâ€™s cause of action arose before the parties were married, and he suffered no symptoms during the marriage.Â  Further, he settled it after they separated.Â  Accordingly, we find the family court did not abuse its discretion in apportioning each partyâ€™s award to them individually.
C.Â  Sale of Marital Home 
Wife maintains the family court erred in ordering the sale of the marital home instead of awarding the home to Husband because Husband was in possession of the home since the separation and the home likely decreased in value as a result of Husbandâ€™s lack of maintenance.Â  We disagree.
To effect an equitable division of property, the family court may require the sale of the marital home. Â Donahue v. Donahue, 299 S.C. 353, 360, 384 S.E.2d 741, 745 (1989). Â Before ordering the sale of marital property, the court should first attempt to make an in-kind distribution of the marital assets. Â Craig, 365 S.C. at 289, 617 S.E.2d at 361.
Husband and Wifeâ€™s marital property, other than the marital home, totaled approximately $21,000.Â  Because the home was valued at $122,000, distributing the home in-kind would have been impossible as the remaining marital estate was inadequate to offset an in-kind award of the home to one spouse.Â  Accordingly, the family court did not abuse its discretion in ordering the sale of the marital home. 
 
D.Â  Special Equity
Husband argues the family court erred in awarding Wife a special equity of $35,000 in the home.Â  We disagree.
Although the house belonged to Wife prior to the marriage, neither party disputes that it is marital property.Â  Accordingly, this determination is the law of the case.Â  Dreher v. Dreher,370 S.C. 75, 78 n.1, 634 S.E.2d 646, 647 n.1 (2006). Â 
The family court awarded Wife a â€œspecial equityâ€ of $35,000 in the home.Â  The family court did not specify why it was awarding Wife such equity, but presumably it was for the $35,000 of equity in the house that Wife brought into the marriage.Â  However, the family court improperly used this term as a spouse only acquires special equity in nonmarital property by contributing to improvements to that nonmarital property. Â Johnson, 296 S.C. at 299, 372 S.E.2d at 113; see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473(5) (Supp. 2006).
While this award does not fit the definition of special equity, we find it was not an abuse of the family courtâ€™s discretion to award Wife her premarital contribution towards the marital home.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the family courtâ€™s award of $35,000 to Wife.
III.Â  Findings of Fact
Wife contends the family court erred in finding Wifeâ€™s behavior brought Husband public embarrassment, financial strain, and worry that Husband would be implicated in the fraud because Husband â€œtook delightâ€ in Wifeâ€™s legal troubles and the financial strain occurred prior to the separation.
The family court made this finding, but it also acknowledged Husband took some personal delight in Wifeâ€™s misfortune.Â  Further, the family court found the money Wife obtained through her financial misdeeds was used for family luxuries, and while Husband may not have condoned it, he should have been more informed and involved with family finances.Â  Accordingly, we find Wife suffered no prejudice as a result of the family courtâ€™s finding.
 
IV.Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Wife contends the family court erred in failing to award her attorneyâ€™s fees but concedes she would only be entitled to them if this Court grants her any relief on appeal.Â  Husband contends the family court erred in failing to award him attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
 
The family court has discretion in deciding whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, and its decision will not be overturned absent an abuse of discretion. Â Donahue, 299 S.C. at 365, 384 S.E.2d at 748.Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the decision is controlled by an error of law or is based on factual findings that are without evidentiary support.Â  
Degenhart, 360 S.C. at 500, 602 S.E.2d at 97. Â 
Section 20-7-420(A)(38) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) authorizes the family court to award attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  In deciding whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, the family court should consider: (1) each partyâ€™s ability to pay his or her own fee; (2) the beneficial results obtained by the attorney; (3) the partiesâ€™ respective financial conditions; and (4) the effect of the fee on each partyâ€™s standard of living.Â  E.D.M., 307 S.C. at 476-77, 415 S.E.2d at 816. Â 
Wifeâ€™s beneficial results may change because of our decision to remand the determination of alimony, so the family court should reconsider the issue of whether to award Wife attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Peirson v. Calhoun, 308 S.C. 246, 255, 417 S.E.2d 604, 609 (Ct. App. 1992); see also Epperly v. Epperly, 312 S.C. 411, 416, 440 S.E.2d 884, 886-87 (1994) (â€œAs to the beneficial result obtained, it is clear that Wife did not prevail in the initial action. However, upon appeal, she has succeeded in part. Â Therefore, this issue is remanded to the [f]amily [c]ourt for reconsideration.â€).Â  However, we find the family court did not err in failing to award Husband attorneyâ€™s fees, considering Husbandâ€™s financial situation is far superior to that of Wife and he has the ability to pay his own fees.
V.Â  Name Change
Wife maintains the family court erred in requiring the clerk of court to notify the State Law Enforcement Division (SLED) of Wifeâ€™s resumption of her maiden name when such notification is not required by section 15-49-20(D) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006).Â  We disagree.
Section 15-49-20(D) provides, â€œIf a petitioner is found to have a criminal record as indicated by the background check and the court grants the petition for a name change, the clerk of court must notify [SLED] of the petitionerâ€™s new name. Â The division must make the appropriate changes to the petitioner's criminal record.â€Â  However, section 15-49-20(J) provides,
 

	The provisions of this section do not apply to a person who wishes to resume her maiden name as a result of a domestic action filed in family court. A family court judge may authorize a name change for a person wishing to resume her maiden name in another order including, but not limited to, an order for separate support and maintenance or a final divorce decree.

Although the section does not require the family court to report Wifeâ€™s name change to SLED, we find the family court did not abuse its discretion in doing so.Â  Wife was not changing her name in an attempt to avoid prosecution or enforcement, but she is a convicted felon.Â  Our research does not reveal any statute or case, nor does Wife point us to any, prohibiting the family court from reporting a name change in a situation similar to the present. 
 
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, the family courtâ€™s order is  
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.
STILWELL, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.[2]

[1] Wife also contends the family court erred (1) in referencing the reasons for the disintegration of the marriage and in failing to make specific findings on Husbandâ€™s contributions to the disintegration of the marriage; (2) in considering her financial misconduct because economic misconduct against a third person is not a factor to be considered in determining distribution of marital property; and (3) in apportioning the equity, taxes, and necessity of repairs of the home to both parties because Husband was in possession of the home and Wife received only $300 per month as an unspecified advance for the use of her interest in the home.
[2] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Charles W. Penland, d/b/a Woodruff Auto Sales, Appellant,
				v.
				State Farm Fire and Casualty Company, Leonard Hinton, Jr., and Tamara J. Hinton, Defendants,
				of whomÂ  State Farm Fire and Casualty Company is the Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-355
Heard June 6, 2007 â€“ Filed July 17, 2007Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				William S.F. Freeman, of Greenville, for Appellant.
				John Kevin Owens, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Â Charles W. Penland, d/b/a Woodruff Auto Sales, (Woodruff) appeals from a jury determination that State Farm Fire and Casualty Company had provided it with notice of cancellation of insurance on a vehicle in which Woodruff was the lienholder.Â  Penland argues the trial court erred in refusing to instruct the jury that State Farm had the burden of proving Woodruff had actually received notice of the cancellation.Â  We affirm.Â 
 
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Leonard Hinton, Jr. and Tamara J. Hinton purchased a Ford Mustang and received financing from Woodruff.Â  The installment sale contract required the Hintons to maintain insurance on the vehicle.Â  Leonard Hinton obtained the required insurance from State Farm.Â  The insurance policyâ€™s declaration page provided the vehicle was financed through Woodruff.Â 
 
State Farm cancelled the policy effective February 11, 2001.Â  Although State Farm employees testified records indicated a computer generated notice of cancellation was sent to Woodruff, the employee for Woodruff responsible for insurance cancellations testified that she never received the notice.Â  After the vehicle was involved in an accident on April 25, 2001, State Farm denied coverage.Â 
 
Woodruff brought this action seeking coverage for the vehicle.Â  During the jury trial, Woodruff requested the court issue the following charge:

	State Farm must prove to you Woodruff Auto actually received State Farmâ€™s notice of the cancellation of the Hintonâ€™s insurance policy.Â  It is not enough that State Farm testifies it mailed the cancellation noticeâ€”State Farm must prove to you the cancellation notice was actually received by Woodruff Auto.Â  
	
	If State Farm fails to prove to you (by a preponderance of the evidence) that the cancellation notice was actually received by Woodruff Auto, you must enter a verdict for Woodruff Auto.Â  
	

The trial court denied Woodruffâ€™s requested charge.Â  The jury found State Farm did mail a notice of cancellation to Woodruff.Â  Thus, the cancellation was effective and there was no coverage for the vehicle at the time of the loss.Â  Woodruff appealed.Â  
 
DISCUSSION
Woodruff argues the trial court erred in refusing to charge the jury that State Farm had to prove the cancellation notice was actually received by Woodruff.Â  We disagree.Â  
 
An appellate court will not reverse the trial courtâ€™s decision regarding jury charges absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Clark v. Cantrell, 339 S.C. 369, 389, 529 S.E.2d 528, 539 (2000).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when the trial courtâ€™s ruling is based on an error of law or, when grounded in factual conclusions, is without evidentiary support.â€Â  Id.Â  The trial court is required to charge only the current and correct law of South Carolina.Â  Frazier v. Badger, 361 S.C. 94, 101, 603 S.E.2d 587, 590 (2004).Â  â€œThe law to be charged to the jury is determined by the evidence at trial.Â  In reviewing jury charges for error, appellate courts must consider the charge as a whole in light of the evidence and issues presented at trial.â€Â  Id.
â€œThe right to cancel a policy can be exercised only in the manner provided in the policy, and the burden of proving a valid cancellation rests on the party asserting it.â€Â  Moore v. Palmetto Bank, 238 S.C. 341, 344-45, 120 S.E.2d 231, 233 (1961). Â In Moore, the court held: 
 

	Where the clause applicable to the insurerâ€™s right to cancel the policy provides for the exercise of such right by mailing of notice to the insuredâ€™s address, or contains substantially similar language, the unanimous rule is that the actual receipt by the insured of such notice is not a condition precedent to a cancellation of the policy by the insurer, and the mere mailing of the letter containing a notice of cancellation is sufficient to effect a cancellation.

Id. at 345, 120 S.E.2d at 233.
In asserting proof of mailing alone was insufficient to effect a valid cancellation in this case, Woodruff relies on Edens v. S.C. Farm Bureau Mutual Ins. Co., 279 S.C. 377, 308 S.E.2d 670 (1983).Â  In Edens, the insurer allegedly sent the notice of cancellation by regular mail, rather than certified or registered, and no return receipt was requested.Â  The insured claimed that he never received notice of cancellation.Â  The policy did not specify the method for giving notice other than to state that cancellation by respondent could be effected by giving to the insured a five daysâ€™ written notice of cancellation.Â  The court found â€œgiving written noticeâ€ meant that the insured shall personally receive the notice in such manner that the insured becomes aware of having received it.Â  Thus, the court held actual receipt was a condition precedent to a cancellation of the policy by the insurer.Â  Id. at 380, 308 S.E.2d at 671.Â  
 
The difference between Moore and Edens lies simply in the language used in the policies.Â  We must therefore look to the language of the State Farm policy to determine whether the policy provided for the mailing of notice to the creditor to be sufficient to effect cancellation.
â€œInsurance policies are subject to the general rules of contract construction.â€ Â Century Indem. Co. v. Golden Hills Builders, Inc., 348 S.C. 559, 565, 561 S.E.2d 355, 358 (2002). Â The court must give policy language its plain, ordinary, and popular meaning. Â Id.Â  The court must read an insurance contract as a whole document so that one may not create an ambiguity by pointing out a single sentence or clause.Â  Schulmeyer v. State Farm Fire Cas. Co., 353 S.C. 491, 495, 579 S.E.2d 132, 134 (2003).Â  â€œThe meaning of a particular word or phrase is not determined by considering the word or phrase by itself, but by reading the policy as a whole and considering the context and subject matter of the insurance contract.â€Â  Id.
In the present case, page 6 of the policy contains a section entitled Financed Vehicles.Â  This section explains to whom the insurer may pay any loss.Â  In addition, the section provides:Â  â€œThe coverage for the creditorâ€™s interest is only valid until we terminate it.Â  . . .Â  The date of termination of the creditorâ€™s interest will be at least 10 days after the date we mail or electronically transmit the termination notice.â€Â  In a subsection of the Conditions section entitled Cancellation, found on page 34 of the policy, are the methods for cancelling the policy.Â  It discusses the methods for the insured to cancel.Â  It also provides the methods for the insured to issue the notice of cancellation: Â â€œWe may cancel your policy by written notice, mailed or delivered to your last known address.Â  The notice shall give the date cancellation is effective. . . .â€Â  In a separate paragraph, the policy provides:Â  â€œThe mailing of notice shall be sufficient proof of notice.â€Â  
 
The section of the policy that specifically deals with cancellation provides for mailing as proof of notice.Â  While other portions of this section seem directed more toward the insured, there is no language in the notice provision limiting its applicability to the insured and not to the creditor.Â  The notice provision does not conflict with any provision in the section involving financed vehicles.Â  Rather, the Financed Vehicles section provides the date of termination counts from the date State Farm â€œmail[s] or electronically transmit[s] the termination notice.â€Â  Thus, this section contemplates notice would be sent by mail or electronic means and counts from the date this notice is sent and not received by the creditor.Â  There is no language in the policy such as that in Edens providing for cancellation only by â€œgiving written notice.â€Â  Reading the policy as a whole, we find it provides for the mailing of notice to be sufficient proof of notice for both the insured and the creditor of a financed vehicle.Â  State Farm did not have to prove actual receipt as a condition precedent to cancellation.Â  Accordingly, the trial court did not err in the denying Woodruffâ€™s requested charge.Â  
 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and BEATTY, JJ. concur.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Anderson County Department of Social Services, Respondent,
				v.
				Mother, Father, and Maternal Grandfather and his wife, Defendants,
				Of Whom Mother is the Appellant.
				In the Interest of the child, DOB 2/17/06.
			
		
	


Appeal From Anderson County
Timothy M. Cain, Family Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-356
Submitted July 2, 2007 â€“ Filed July 24, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Hugh Wingo Welborn, of Anderson, for Appellant.Â 
				
				Dottie C. Ingram, of Anderson, for Respondent.Â  
				
				Amy Marie Parker, of Greenville, for Guardian Ad Litem.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Mother appeals the family courtâ€™s finding that she neglected the child.[1]Â  We affirm.[2] 
 
FACTS
On April 30, 2006, Father cared for the infant child while Mother showered.Â  Father yelled for Mother, saying the child was blue from the waist down.Â  Mother loosened the childâ€™s diaper in case it was too tight.Â  The child was fussy following the incident and needed to be constantly held.Â  He also had a red mark on his face.Â  Father indicated the mark likely came from Father putting the child against Fatherâ€™s chest, resulting in his cheek hitting Fatherâ€™s collar bone.Â  Mother later contacted her mother, who was a registered nurse, and she instructed Mother to take the child to the hospital.Â 
 
The following day, Grandmother saw the childâ€™s pediatrician at the hospital. Â She asked the doctor if Mother had brought the child in to see her.Â  Grandmother mentioned the blue coloration on the childâ€™s legs.Â  That night, Mother called the doctorâ€™s after-hours number.Â  Mother finally brought the child to see the doctor the following day, two days after the incident.Â 
 
According to the doctor, the only visible injury was the red mark on the childâ€™s face.Â  However, the child was still fussy when the doctor examined him.Â  Following x-rays, the child was diagnosed with multiple leg fractures and a rib fracture.Â  The doctor, who testified as an expert, determined the injuries resulted from non-accidental trauma.Â  
 
Additionally, the doctor testified regarding her previous experiences treating the child.Â  The doctor first saw him when the child was five days old.Â  The doctor began treating him for reflux with medication when he was four weeks old.Â  Reflux causes children to cry and display signs of discomfort.Â  The childâ€™s reflux medication lessened his fussiness.Â 
 
The doctor also testified she found a mark on the childâ€™s foot during an earlier checkup, but no broken bones were revealed by an x-ray.Â  She also testified Mother has done everything requested of her, attended all appointments, and asked appropriate questions.Â  
 
Following the discovery of the childâ€™s bone fractures, the Department of Social Services placed the child with Grandmother and allowed Mother to stay with her also.Â  Father did not attend his scheduled appointment with the department.Â  By telephone, Father told the department that either Mother or Grandmother caused the childâ€™s injuries.Â  The child currently is in the care of Motherâ€™s father (maternal grandfather) and his current wife.Â  They both testified the child is thriving in their care.Â  Mother visits the child often, and the department developed a treatment plan for Mother.Â 
 
The guardian ad litem reported the childâ€™s needs are being met at the maternal grandfatherâ€™s home.Â  The guardian testified she believes the parties involved know more about the situation than they are saying.Â  The guardian does not believe Mother hurt the child.Â  Mother and Grandmother each briefly testified and asserted their Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination.Â  Father did not appear at the trial.Â 
 
The family court found by a preponderance of evidence that Father abused and Mother neglected the child.Â  These findings were entered into the Central Registry for Child Abuse and Neglect.Â  The maternal grandfather and his wife were given legal custody and retained physical custody of the child.Â  The family court adopted the departmentâ€™s treatment plan requiring Mother to submit to evaluations, take classes, provide child support, and understand the importance of providing for the childâ€™s physical, medical, and educational needs.Â 
 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn appeals from family court, the appellate court has the authority to find the facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  S. C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Meek, 352 S.C. 523, 528, 575 S.E.2d 846, 848 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  However, this court is not required to ignore that the family court was in a better position to evaluate witness credibility and assign weight to testimony.Â  Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 452, 477 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. App. 1996).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Mother argues that the family court erred in finding Mother neglected the child by the preponderance of the evidence.Â  We disagree.
Section 20-7-736(F) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) states:

	The court shall not order that a child be removed from the custody of the parent or guardian unless the court finds that the allegations of the petition are supported by a preponderance of evidence including a finding that the child is an abused or neglected child as defined in Section 20-7-490 and that retention of the child in or return of the child to the home would place the child at unreasonable risk of harm affecting the childâ€™s life, physical health or safety, or mental well-being and the child cannot reasonably be protected from this harm without being removed.

Section 20-7-490(2)(a) & (c) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) explains that child neglect occurs if the parent, guardian, or other person responsible for the welfare of the child:

	(a)  inflicts or allows to be inflicted upon the child physical or mental injury or engages in acts or omissions which present a substantial risk of physical or mental injury to the child . . . [or]
	(c)  fails to supply the child with adequate food, clothing, shelter, or education as required under Article 1 of Chapter 65 of Title 59, supervision appropriate to the childâ€™s age and development, or health care though financially able to do so or offered financial or other reasonable means to do so and the failure to do so has caused or presents a substantial risk of causing physical or mental injury. . . . Â For the purpose of this chapter â€œadequate health careâ€ includes any medical or nonmedical remedial health care permitted or authorized under state law.

The family court heard testimony that a non-accidental trauma befell the child while Mother was in the shower.Â  Subsequently, Mother waited two days after discovering the childâ€™s legs were blue before taking the child to a doctor or hospital.Â  In addition, there existed other evidence of injury, including a red mark on the childâ€™s face and the child wanting to be held constantly.Â  Although Mother did bring the child to see the doctor two days following the trauma, we concur with the family court that even though Mother may have intended no harm to the child, a preponderance of the evidence shows Mother was neglectful in failing to obtain appropriate medical care.
 
AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]  The names of the parties are deleted to conceal the minorâ€™s identity.
[2]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
