text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 

PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Ronald M. Defeo, Respondent,
				v.
				Community Services Associates, Inc.; Sea Pines Company, Inc.; Sea Pines Architectural Review Corporation, Inc.; White Hat Properties, Inc.; and Analytical Business Services, Defendants,
				Of whom White Hat Properties, Inc. is the Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal from Beaufort County
Â Curtis L. Coltrane, Master-in-Equity
Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-357
Heard June 6, 2007 â€“ Filed July 24, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Richard D. Bybee, of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellant.
				Dean B. Bell, of Hilton Head Island, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Â White Hat Properties, Inc. (White Hat) appeals the master-in-equityâ€™s order enjoining White Hat from constructing a residence on its lot.Â  On appeal, White Hat contends the master erred in finding the lot was restricted to golf course use only and excluding extrinsic evidence of the intent behind the alleged restriction.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On May 9, 1997, Ronald M. Defeo purchased Lot 22 in the Red Maple Road Subdivision of Sea Pines Plantation on Hilton Head Island.Â  A golf course surrounds Red Maple Road Subdivision.Â  The deed by which Defeo obtained Lot 22 incorporates a plat (the Plat) describing the property conveyed.Â  The Plat, recorded by the developer of Sea Pines Plantation in 1970, shows a parcel of property (the Lot) adjacent to Lot 22 labeled only as â€œRESERVED FOR FUTURE USE FOR GOLF COURSE.â€Â 
 
On January 10, 2000, Community Services Associates, Inc., and Sea Pines Company, Inc., the successors-in-interest to the developer of Sea Pines Plantation, transferred the Lot to Sea Pines Land Company.Â  Sea Pines Land Company subsequently changed its name to White Hat and prepared to build a residence on the Lot.Â  In response, Defeo filed the present action seeking to enjoin White Hatâ€™s use of the Lot.[1] 
 
At trial, Francis Guscio, Jr., formerly the land control officer for the developer of Sea Pines Plantation and currently an owner and officer of White Hat, attempted to testify as to why the term â€œreservedâ€ was used on the Plat, rather than the term â€œrestricted.â€Â  The master refused to allow the testimony, holding â€œ[f]irsthand knowledge of how that language got put on that plat is what would be required.â€Â  White Hat proffered Guscioâ€™s testimony.Â  White Hat also proffered the expert testimony of George Richardson Wieters, a real estate attorney and a licensed title insurance agent, as to whether the term â€œRESERVED FOR FUTURE USE FOR GOLF COURSEâ€ was ambiguous.Â  The master excluded the testimony on the ground it constituted a legal conclusion.
 
Subsequently, the master issued an order finding the language on the Plat unambiguously restricted the Lot to golf course use only.Â  As a result, the master permanently enjoined White Hatâ€™s proposed residential use of the Lot.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œAn action to enforce restrictive covenants by injunction is in equity.â€Â  Seabrook Island Prop. Owners Assâ€™n v. Marshland Trust, Inc., 358 S.C. 655, 661, 596 S.E.2d 380, 383 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œIn equitable actions, the appellate court may review the record and make findings of fact in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Grosshuesch v. Cramer, 367 S.C. 1, 4, 623 S.E.2d 833, 834 (2005).Â  However, the appellate court is not required to ignore the findings of the master, because he was in a better position to evaluate the credibility of the witnesses.Â  Siau v. Kassel, 369 S.C. 631, 638, 632 S.E.2d 888, 892 (Ct. App. 2006).
A decision whether to grant or deny an injunction is ordinarily left to the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  County of Richland v. Simpkins, 348 S.C. 664, 668, 560 S.E.2d 902, 904 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when there is an error of law or a factual conclusion which is without evidentiary support. Lee v. Suess, 318 S.C. 283, 285, 457 S.E.2d 344, 345 (1995).
DISCUSSION
I.  The Plat
White Hat contends the master erred in finding the Plat unambiguously restricted use of the Lot to golf course purposes only.[2] Â We disagree.
â€œRestrictive covenants are contractual in nature.â€Â  Seabrook Island Prop. Ownersâ€™ Assâ€™n v. Berger, 365 S.C. 234, 239, 616 S.E.2d 431, 434 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  â€œThe language of a restrictive covenant is to be construed according to the plain and ordinary meaning attributed to it at the time of execution.â€ Hardy v. Aiken, 369 S.C. 160, 166, 631 S.E.2d 539, 542 (2006). Â â€œA restrictive covenant is ambiguous when its terms are reasonably susceptible of more than one interpretation.â€Â Â  Id. at 165, 631 S.E.2d at 541. 
 
â€œA restriction on the use of property must be created in express terms or by plain and unmistakable implication, and all such restrictions are to be strictly construed, with all doubts resolved in favor of the free use of the property.â€Â  Hamilton v. CCM, Inc., 274 S.C. 152, 157, 263 S.E.2d 378, 380 (1980) (citation omitted).Â  However, â€œ[t]he rule of strict construction governing restrictive covenants does not preclude their enforcement.Â  A restrictive covenant will be enforced if the covenant expresses the partyâ€™s intent or purpose, and this rule will not be used to defeat the clear express language of the covenant.â€Â  Sea Pines Plantation Co. v. Wells, 294 S.C. 266, 270, 363 S.E.2d 891, 894 (1987).
Restrictive covenants may be created several ways, the most common of which are: Â (1) by deed; (2) by declaration; and (3) by implication from a general plan or scheme of development.Â  Queenâ€™s Grant II Horizontal Prop. Regime v. Greenwood Dev. Corp., 368 S.C. 342, 362, 628 S.E.2d 902, 913 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  When a deed describes land as shown on a certain plat, such plat becomes a part of the deed.Â  Carolina Land Co. v. Bland, 265 S.C. 98, 105, 217 S.E.2d 16, 19 (1975); Bennett v. Investors Title Ins. Co., 370 S.C. 578, 594, 635 S.E.2d 649, 657 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  
 
At issue in this case, is the term â€œreserveâ€ as used in the Plat.Â  â€œReserveâ€ means â€œ[s]omething retained or stored for future use.â€Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 1334 (8th ed. 2004).Â  White Hat concentrates on the word â€œreservedâ€ and contends the developer, who recorded the Plat, used this language to â€œreserveâ€ his right to develop the Lot for golf course use.Â  However, White Hat also asserts this reservation did not affect the developerâ€™s right to use the Lot for other purposes, such as for residential use.Â  While we agree the developer clearly intended to reserve his right to develop the Lot for golf course purposes, nothing in the phrase conveys a similar intent to develop the Lot for non-golf course use.[3]Â  Accordingly, we hold the clear, unambiguous language of the Plat restricts the Lot to golf course use only.Â  
 
II. Extrinsic Evidence
White Hat argues the master erred in disallowing: Â (1) Guscioâ€™s testimony of why the developer used the term â€œreservedâ€ as opposed to â€œrestricted;â€ and (2) Wietersâ€™s opinion as to whether the term â€œreservedâ€ was ambiguous. Â We disagree.
â€œThe admission and rejection of testimony is largely within the trial judgeâ€™s sound discretion and will not be disturbed on appeal absent a showing that the trial court abused its discretion or its decision was controlled by an error of law.â€Â  Mishoe v. QHG of Lake City, Inc., 366 S.C. 195, 203, 621 S.E.2d 363, 367 (Ct. App. 2005), cert. denied (Jan. 18, 2007).
Initially, we find the master correctly excluded Guscioâ€™s and Wietersâ€™s testimony as extrinsic evidence. â€œWhere the language used in a restrictive covenant is unambiguous, there is no room for construction and the language must be enforced in accordance with its plain meaning.â€ Heape v. Broxton, 293 S.C. 343, 345, 360 S.E.2d 157, 158 (Ct. App. 1987); see C.A.N. Enters., Inc. v. S.C. Health & Human Servs. Fin. Commâ€™n, 296 S.C. 373, 377-78, 373 S.E.2d 584, 586 (1988) (â€œExtrinsic evidence giving the contract a different meaning from that indicated by its plain terms is inadmissible.â€); see also Moser v. Gosnell, 334 S.C. 425, 431, 513 S.E.2d 123, 126 (Ct. App. 1999) (stating when a covenant is clear and unambiguous, the court looks only to the language of the covenant and not to extrinsic evidence to determine the intent of the parties).Â  
 
Moreover, White Hat contends the master should have allowed Guscioâ€™s testimony under the business records exception to the hearsay rule, Rule 803(6) of the South Carolina Rules of Evidence.[4]Â  However, White Hat never laid a proper foundation for the application of this exception. Â Nor did he argue this exception to the master.Â  Accordingly, we are unable to determine whether Guscioâ€™s testimony would lie within this exception and decline to rule on the merits.Â  See Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000) (â€œIt is well-settled that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved for appellate review.â€); Ellie, Inc. v. Miccichi, 358 S.C. 78, 103, 594 S.E.2d 485, 498 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œWithout an initial ruling by the trial court, a reviewing court simply would not be able to evaluate whether the trial court committed error.â€); see also Webb v. CSX Transp., Inc., 364 S.C. 639, 655, 615 S.E.2d 440, 449 (2005) (â€œIt is the appellantâ€™s burden to present a sufficient record for appellate review.â€).
Additionally, Guscioâ€™s proffered testimony was almost identical to Guscioâ€™s answer to a previous question, to which Defeo failed to object.Â  Thus, even if the master erred in excluding the testimony, any error would be harmless given the testimony would have been cumulative. Â See Smith v. Winningham, 252 S.C. 462, 467, 166 S.E.2d 825, 827 (1969) (â€œAlleged error in the exclusion of offered testimony is of no avail if the same testimony or testimony to the same effect had been or was afterwards allowed to be given by the witness.â€); S.C. Depâ€™t of Highways & Pub. Transp. v. Galbreath, 315 S.C. 82, 86, 431 S.E.2d 625, 628 (Ct. App. 1993)(stating, â€œ[e]ven if the trial court erred in excluding evidence, there is no reversible error where the testimony would have been cumulativeâ€).
Further, Wietersâ€™s testimony, though based upon his analysis as a title examiner, amounted to a legal conclusion.Â  Accordingly, the master did not abuse his discretion in excluding it.Â  See Dawkins v. Fields, 354 S.C. 58, 66, 580 S.E.2d 433, 437 (2003) (â€œIn general, expert testimony on issues of law is inadmissible.â€).
CONCLUSION
We find the Plat clearly and unambiguously restricted the Lotâ€™s use to golf purposes.Â  In light of this ruling, the master did not err in refusing to consider Guscioâ€™s lay testimony and Wietersâ€™s expert opinion.Â  Therefore, the masterâ€™s decision is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] Â While Defeo included other parties and causes of action in his original and amended complaints, these parties and claims were dismissed during trial.Â  Defeo does not appeal this dismissal.
[2]Â  In its brief, White Hat lists six issues.Â  In the interest of brevity and clarity, we have consolidated our discussion to two issues.
[3]  Although this evidence does not affect our decision, we note other plats recorded by the same developer contained the expression, â€œRESERVED FOR POSSIBLE USE FOR GOLF VILLAS AND CLUB PARKING.â€Â  (emphasis added).Â  This language appropriately conveys to future purchasers the grantorâ€™s intent to use property for golf course purposes without forfeiting any right to use the property for other allowable purposes.
[4]Â Â Rule 803(6) provides:

	A memorandum, report, record, or data compilation, in any form, of acts, events, conditions, or diagnoses, made at or near the time by, or from information transmitted by, a person with knowledge, if kept in the course of a regularly conducted business activity, and if it was the regular practice of that business activity to make the memorandum, report, record, or data compilation, all as shown by the testimony of the custodian or other qualified witness, unless the source of information or the method or circumstances of preparation indicate lack of trustworthiness; 
	provided, however, that subjective opinions and judgments found in business records are not admissible. The term â€œbusinessâ€ as used in this subsection includes business, institution, association, profession, occupation, and calling of every kind, whether or not conducted for profit.

Rule 803(6), SCRE.

THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Edith Karoly,
          Individually and as Personal Representative of the Estate of John P. Karoly,
          Sr., Deceased, John P. Karoly, Jr., Peter J. Karoly, Joseph Karoly, Joanne
          Billman, Candice Pamerleau, Kim Jacobs and Michael Karoly, Appellants,
        v.
        Stephen Sumner,
          Carolina Funeral Services, Inc., Calvin C. Shankle, Weber Funeral Homes,
          Inc., and Service Corporation International, Defendants,
        of whom Calvin
          C. Shankle and Weber Funeral Homes, Inc., are the
          Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
  Â R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2007-UP-360
Heard June 6, 2007 â€“ Filed July 31, 2007 

Â AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Brooks Roberts Fudenberg, of Charleston, Geoffrey H. Waggoner, of
          Mt. Pleasant, and Jeffrey G. Weber, of Kernersville, for Appellants.
        Merritt Abney, of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER
  CURIAM: Â Edith Karoly, individually
  and as personal representative of the Estate of John P. Karoly, Sr., along with
  other family members (collectively â€œAppellantsâ€) appeal the circuit courtâ€™s
  order dismissing all claims except their breach of contract claim against Respondents
  Calvin C. Shankle (â€œShankleâ€) and Weber Funeral Homes, Inc (â€œWeberâ€).Â 
  In their brief, Appellants contend the circuit court erred in dismissing their
  negligence per se claim pursuant to the Full Faith and Credit Clause of the
  United States Constitution and the doctrine of res judicata.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On July 21,
  2002, John P. Karoly, Sr., (â€œthe decedentâ€) passed away at the Medical
  University of South Carolina.Â  On the date of the decedentâ€™s death, one of the
  decedentâ€™s sons, John P. Karoly, Jr., contracted with Weber and Service
  Corporation International on behalf of the estate for the removal, preparation,
  and transportation of the decedentâ€™s body from South Carolina to Pennsylvania. Â Weber, in turn, contracted with Carolina Funeral Services, Inc., for the
  removal, preparation, care, embalming, and transportation of the decedentâ€™s
  corpse from South Carolina to Pennsylvania.Â  Upon arrival in Pennsylvania, the
  family was to be permitted to identify, view, and pay their last respects prior
  to cremation of the decedent.
After receiving
  the decedentâ€™s remains, Carolina Funeral Services assigned Stephen Sumner to
  perform the embalming and preparation.Â  However, Sumner either did not embalm
  or failed to properly embalm the decedentâ€™s body. Â When the decedentâ€™s body
  arrived in Pennsylvania, the corpse was in an advanced state of decomposition.Â 
  This precluded the family from conducting a viewing of the body, and local
  friends and family were not able to pay their respects.
On September 30,
  2004, Appellants filed a complaint in Pennsylvania.Â  The Pennsylvania Complaint
  included the following causes of action against Weber and Shankle:Â  (1)
  intentional/negligent mishandling of a corpse; (2) negligence per se based on
  18 Pa. C.S.A. Â§ 5510 (1972); (3) breach of contract; and (4)
  intentional/negligent infliction of emotional distress.Â  On January 24, 2005,
  the Court of Common Pleas of Lehigh County, Pennsylvania, entered an order dismissing
  all but one of Appellantsâ€™ claims; the only claim that remained was the breach
  of contract claim.Â  With regard to Appellantsâ€™ claim for intentional infliction
  of emotional distress, the court rejected Weber and Shankleâ€™s argument that Pennsylvania law does not recognize that cause of action.Â  Nevertheless, the court held
  that Appellants had failed to state any facts to support a claim that Weber and
  Shankle intentionally mistreated the decedentâ€™s corpse.Â  Further, finding that Pennsylvania law does not permit recovery for the negligent mishandling of a corpse, the
  court dismissed, without leave to amend, any and all allegations regarding the
  negligence of Weber and Shankle.Â  Finally, the court dismissed the negligence per
  se cause of action because 18 Pa. C.S.A. Â§ 5510 only prohibits intentional acts.
  Â Thus, the court reasoned that â€œ[b]y its nature, negligence cannot flow from an
  intentional act.â€Â  Appellants neither appealed nor moved to alter or amend the order.Â 
  Appellants subsequently dismissed without prejudice their remaining breach of
  contract claim still pending in Pennsylvania.
On July 20,
  2005, Appellants filed the instant action in South Carolina. Â The South
  Carolina Amended Complaint included the same causes of action and is nearly
  identical to the Pennsylvania Complaint, except the negligence per se cause of
  action was predicated on South Carolina Code section 16-17-600 (Supp. 2005).
Following Weber
  and Shankleâ€™s Motion to Dismiss,[1] filed December 2, 2005, the circuit court allowed the breach of contract cause
  of action to continue, but dismissed the other causes of action under the
  theory of res judicata and the Full Faith and Credit Clause of the United
  States Constitution.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Under
  Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, a defendant may move to dismiss based upon a plaintiffâ€™s failure
  to allege facts constituting a cause of action.Â  Baird v. Charleston County, 333 S.C. 519, 527, 511 S.E.2d 69, 73 (1999).Â  The trial judge may dismiss the
  claim if the defendant demonstrates the plaintiff has failed â€œto state facts
  sufficient to constitute a cause of actionâ€ in the pleadings filed with the
  court.Â  Williams v. Condon, 347 S.C. 227, 232-33, 553 S.E.2d 496, 499
  (Ct. App. 2001) (quoting Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP).Â  When considering the motion to
  dismiss for failure to state a claim, the trial court must base its ruling
  solely upon the allegations made on the face of the complaint.Â  Baird,
  333 S.C. at 527, 511 S.E.2d at 73; Stiles v. Onorato, 318 S.C. 297, 300,
  457 S.E.2d 601, 602 (1995).Â  If the facts and inferences drawn from the facts
  alleged in the complaint would entitle the plaintiff to relief on any theory,
  then the grant of a motion to dismiss for failure to state
  a claim is improper.Â  Brown v. Leverette, 291 S.C. 364, 366, 353 S.E.2d
  697, 698 (1987); McCormick v. England, 328 S.C. 627, 632-33, 494 S.E.2d
  431, 433 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  The facts and inferences alleged in the complaint
  are viewed in the light most favorable to the plaintiff.Â  Toussaint v. Ham,
  292 S.C. 415, 416, 357 S.E.2d 8, 9 (1987); Cowart v. Poore, 337 S.C.
  359, 364, 523 S.E.2d 182, 184-85 (Ct. App. 1999).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellants
  contend the circuit court erred in dismissing their negligence per se cause of
  action against Shankle and Weber based on the Full Faith and Credit Clause and
  the doctrine of res judicata because their claim is based on the South Carolina statute which is different from their claim based on the Pennsylvania
  statute.Â  We disagree.
The Full Faith and Credit
  Clause of the United States Constitution provides that â€œFull Faith and Credit
  shall be given in each State to the . . . judicial Proceedings of every other
  State.â€Â U.S. Const. art. IV, Â§ 1.Â 
  The thrust of the clause is that courts of one state must give such force and
  effect to a foreign judgment as the judgment would
  receive in the issuing state. Â Â Purdie v. Smalls, 293
  S.C. 216, 219-20, 359 S.E.2d 306, 308 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  As a result, â€œa foreign
  judgment which is regular on its face generally may not be collaterally
  attacked.â€Â Bankers Trust Co. v.
    Braten, 317 S.C. 547, 550, 455 S.E.2d 199, 200 (Ct. App. 1995).
As the Appellants
  concede, in order to determine the res judicata effect of the Pennsylvania
  order upon the present action, this court must decide whether Appellants would
  be precluded from pursuing their claims in the courts of Pennsylvania. Â In
  Pennsylvania, as in South Carolina, â€œ[i]t is hornbook law that when a final
  judgment on the merits has been rendered by a court of competent jurisdiction,
  the doctrine of res judicata will bar any future suit on the same cause of
  action between the same parties.â€ Â Glynn v. Glynn, 789 A. 2d 242, 249 (Pa. Super. Ct. 2001). Â Under Pennsylvania law:

  Res
    judicata encompasses two related, yet distinct principles: technical res judicata
    and collateral estoppel. Â Henion v. Workersâ€™ Comp Appeal Bd. (Firpo &
      Sons, Inc.), 776 A.2d. 362 (Pa. Cmwlth., 2001). Â Technical res judicata
    provides that where a final judgment on the merits exists, a future lawsuit on
    the same cause of action is precluded. Â Id. Â Collateral estoppel acts to
    foreclose litigation in a subsequent action where issues of law or fact were
    actually litigated and necessary to a previous final judgment. Â Id.
  Technical
    res judicata requires the coalescence of four factors: (1) identity of the
    thing sued upon or for; (2) identity of the causes of action; (3) identity of
    the persons or parties to the action; and (4) identity of the quality or
    capacity of the parties suing or being sued. Â Id. Â Res judicata applies
    to claims that were actually litigated as well as those matters that should
    have been litigated. Â Id. Â Generally, causes of action are identical
    when the subject matter and the ultimate issues are the same in both the old
    and new proceedings. Â Id.
  Similarly,
    collateral estoppel bars a subsequent lawsuit where (1) an issue decided in a
    prior action is identical to one presented in a later action, (2) the prior
    action resulted in a final judgment on the merits, (3) the party against whom
    collateral estoppel is asserted was a party to the prior action, or is in
    privity with a party to the prior actions, and (4) the party against whom
    collateral estoppel is asserted had a full and fair opportunity to litigate the
    issue in the prior action. Â Rue v. K-Mart Corp., 552 Pa. 13, 713 A. 2d
    82 (1998).

Stilp v. Commonwealth,
  910 A. 2d 775, 783-84 (Pa. Commw. Ct. 2006).
Moreover,
  â€œan order of dismissal â€˜with prejudiceâ€™ made upon agreement or stipulation of
  the parties before trial, or by the court after trial, is a judgment on the merits
  and operates as res judicata of the issues addressed in the case, thus barring
  a subsequent suit on the same cause of action.â€ Â Waynik v. Suhyda, 22 Pa. D. & C.2d 208, 213 (Pa.Ct.Com.Pl.1960). Â Further,
  a dismissal upon preliminary objections is a final order which becomes res
  judicata if not timely appealed. Â U.S. Natâ€™l Bank in Johnstown v.
    Johnson, 487 A.2d 809, 813 (Pa. 1985).
In
  essence, Appellants contend the Pennsylvania court did not make specific
  factual findings or issue any ruling concerning the South Carolina statute in
  question. Â Thus, they argue, the circuit court erred in holding the issue of
  negligence per se based on the South Carolina statute was fully and fairly
  decided in the Pennsylvania action. Â While the Pennsylvania court did
  not base its dismissal of the negligence per se cause of action on our statute,
  it did conclude that the Pennsylvania statute, like our statute, only prohibits
  intentional, as opposed to negligent conduct, and that the Appellants had not alleged
  that Weber and Shankle engaged in intentional conduct. Â The court further
  concluded that â€œ[b]y its nature, negligence cannot flow from an intentional
  act.â€ Â Comparing the language of the two statutes, our statute reads in
  relevant part as follows:

  (A) It is
    unlawful for a person willfully and knowingly, and without proper legal
    authority to:
  (1) destroy or
    damage the remains of a deceased human being;
  (2) . . .; or
  (3) desecrate human remains.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-17-600 (Supp. 2005).
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The Pennsylvania statute reads
  in pertinent part:

  
    Except as authorized by law, a person who treats a corpse in a way
      that he knows would outrage ordinary family sensibilities commits a misdemeanor
      of the second degree.[2]
  

18 Pa. C.S.A. Â§ 5510 (1972).
Although the two
  statutes read differently, the conduct both statutes prescribe is the intentional
  or willful abuse of a corpse. Â Inasmuch as the Pennsylvania court held Weber
  and Shankle had not alleged an intentional abuse of the decedentâ€™s body, and
  further held as a matter of law that negligence cannot be predicated on an
  intentional act, we are constrained to hold under principles of res judicata
  and collateral estoppel[3] that the circuit court did not err in dismissing Appellantsâ€™ negligence per se
  cause of action.
CONCLUSION
We
  find Appellants abandoned their issues on appeal relating to the dismissal of all
  of their causes of action except their claim based on negligence per se.Â  Based
  on the above reasoning, we conclude the circuit court did not err in dismissing
  Appellantsâ€™ negligence per se cause of action.Â  Accordingly, the decision of
  the circuit court is 
AFFIRMED.
BEATTY and WILLIAMS, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.


[1] Â The motion to dismiss, in addition to arguing res
  judicata and collateral estoppel, also asserts that â€œ[b]oth [statesâ€™] statutes
  relied upon by [Appellants] to support their claims for negligence per se
  prohibit intentional, as opposed to negligent, acts. Â Because negligence cannot
  flow from an intentional act, the statutes relied upon provide no basis for a
  claim of negligence per se.â€
[2] Â Arguably, one could assert this statute permits
  recovery based on gross negligence. Â However, Appellants did not appeal the
  Pennsylvania courtâ€™s holding that the statute prohibits only intentional acts.Â 
  That holding, therefore, becomes res judicata.
[3] Â This court may affirm a decision of the trial court
  based on any ground appearing in the record.Â  Rule 220(c), SCACR. Â Moreover,
  collateral estoppel was discussed during oral argument before this court.

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Wendell L.
          Muckenfuss, and Thomas D. Muckenfuss, III, Respondents,
        v.
        Pauline T.
          Muckenfuss, an alleged incapacitated adult, Paul M. Muckenfuss, Sr., and
          Pauline J. Oâ€™Keefe, her next of kin, Defendants,
        of whom Pauline
          J. Oâ€™Keefe is the Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
  Â J. C. Buddy Nicholson, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-361
Heard April 5, 2007 â€“ Filed July 31, 2007

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        Dennis James Christensen, of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellant.
        Nat B. Benson, Jr., of Mt. Pleasant, Sarah L. Clingman, of
          Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Jane
  Oâ€™Keefe (Daughter) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order affirming the probate
  courtâ€™s orders appointing third parties as Pauline Muckenfussâ€™s (Motherâ€™s)
  guardian and conservator. Â Daughter argues the probate court failed to make the
  necessary finding of good cause to bypass her statutorily-designated priority
  as Motherâ€™s attorney-in-fact.Â  Because we find the probate court failed to make
  the requisite finding and the circuit court erred in affirming the probate
  courtâ€™s orders, we reverse and remand for proceedings consistent with this
  opinion.
FACTS
Mother is a widow who lives at an
  assisted-living facility, the Savannah House in Charleston.Â  In addition to
  Daughter, Mother has three sons: Thomas (Tommy), Wendell, and Paul.Â  Daughter
  was designated as Motherâ€™s power of attorney in October 2002.Â  Mother was
  admitted to the Savannah House in November 2002, following hospitalization for
  mental illness.
On
  January 29, 2004, Wendell and Tommy petitioned the probate court to find Mother
  incapacitated and to appoint a guardian and conservator.Â  The probate court
  conducted a hearing on September 15, 2004.Â  At trial, Dr. Susan Hardesty of the
  Medical University of South Carolina testified Mother needed a guardian and
  conservator. Â Dr. Hardesty stated to a reasonable degree of medical certainty that
  Motherâ€™s capacity did not allow her to manage her resources.Â  
The hearing also included testimony regarding the relationship
  between the children and the affect the friction between the siblings had on
  Mother.Â  Dr. Hardesty testified that Mother felt paranoid regarding her
  childrenâ€™s roles.Â  Dr. Hardesty was not certain if having one of Motherâ€™s
  children serve as a guardian or conservator would aggravate Motherâ€™s condition
  because Motherâ€™s reaction would be dependent on her paranoid ideation at the
  time.Â  Additionally, Dr. Hardesty stated any suggestions by Mother regarding
  who should be the guardian or conservator should not be given weight by the
  court.Â  
The guardian ad litem testified Mother was concerned over the conflict
  between her children.Â  The guardian believed a third party serving as guardian
  and conservator would be in the best interest of everyone given the infighting
  between Daughter and the sons.Â  The guardian believed a third party could
  circumvent current communication problems, but the animosity between Daughter
  and the sons will likely remain regardless of whether a third party is used.Â  The
  guardian testified he had no problem with the way Daughter provided care for
  Mother and handled Motherâ€™s finances. 
The friction between the siblings was illustrated by trial
  testimony.Â  Paul testified he had to call the police department to locate
  Mother after Mother moved to the Savannah House because no one informed him of the
  move.Â  Paul thought Daughter had done a good job providing for Mother; however,
  he believed having a third party involved in Motherâ€™s care would be best for
  everyone. 
Wendell also requested a third partyâ€™s involvement in order to
  reduce the infighting in the family and minimize Motherâ€™s paranoia towards her
  children.Â  Regarding the friction, Wendell testified Daughter would not allow
  him to visit Mother privately on one occasion.Â  Wendell further testified Daughterâ€™s
  husband followed Wendell to the airport and behaved suspiciously.Â  
According
  to Daughter, she gets along well with Tommy and Paul, but has difficulty with Wendell.Â 
  Daughter testified she did not tell her brothers she had power of attorney because
  Mother requested she not tell them.Â  Regarding Motherâ€™s relocation to the Savannah
  House, Daughter explained she notified the oldest brother, Tommy, and assumed
  he would notify the other two brothers.Â  Over the three years prior to the
  hearing, Daughter testified she has spoken with or seen Paul and Tommy numerous
  times, but only contacted Wendell twice.Â  
In response to Wendellâ€™s statement that Daughter refused to allow
  him to see Mother, Daughter stated she suggested Wendell not meet with Mother
  alone because Mother had not seen Wendell in years and it would be too shocking
  for Mother.Â  According to Daughter, while Wendell was speaking to Mother that
  day, a Savannah House employee informed Daughter that Motherâ€™s whole body was
  shaking.Â  
The aforementioned Savannah House employee, Patty Daniel, testified
  she had no concerns over Daughterâ€™s handling of Mother.Â  Daniel and Daughter
  both stated they believe the system in place prior to trial, with Daughter
  serving as attorney-in-fact, worked fine.Â  Daniel acknowledged that the only
  problem she saw under the system was Mother gets very agitated by Wendellâ€™s
  phone conversations.Â  Daniel believed it is easier to deal with a family member
  than a third party.Â  
On
  October 19, 2004, the probate court ordered third parties Seniors Choice and
  First Southeast Fiduciary and Trust Services, Incorporated to serve as Motherâ€™s
  guardian and conservator, respectively.Â  Daughter appealed the orders to the
  circuit court.Â  On May 23, 2006, the circuit court affirmed the probate court.Â 
  After a hearing, the circuit court held the probate court did not abuse its
  discretion in finding that Motherâ€™s best interest would be served by appointing
  third parties as guardian and conservator.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œ[T]he
  determination of the standard of review by an appellate court of matters
  originating in the probate court is controlled by whether the cause of action
  is at law or in equity.â€ Â Dean v. Kilgore, 313 S.C. 257, 259, 437 S.E.2d
  154, 155 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  â€œTo make this determination, the appellate court
  must look to the essential character of the cause of action alleged by the
  petitioners in the court below.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œPersons of unsound mind, like
  infants, are under the special protection of the courts of equity with respect
  to their persons, property, and legal transactions.â€Â  Shepard v. First Am.
    Mortgage Co., 289 S.C. 516, 518, 347 S.E.2d 118, 119 (Ct. App. 1986); see Dean, 313 S.C. at 259, 437 S.E.2d at 155 (finding petition to
  remove personal representative is in equity); Gaddy v. Douglass, 359
  S.C. 329, 333, 597 S.E.2d 12, 14 (Ct. App. 2004) (recognizing an action to set aside a power of attorney and an
  instrument revoking a power of attorney on the ground of a lack of mental
  capacity sounds in equity). Â If the
  probate proceeding is equitable in nature, an appellate court may make factual
  findings according to its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  In
    re Howard, 315 S.C. 356, 362, 434 S.E.2d 254, 257-58 (1993).Â  Therefore,
  â€œ[b]eing an equity case, the circuit court, sitting as an appellate court, had
  jurisdiction to make findings in accordance with its own view of the
  preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Eagles v. S.C. Natâ€™l Bank, 301 S.C.
  402, 408, 392 S.E.2d 187, 191 (Ct. App. 1990).
The
  two-judge rule applies to appeals from the probate court to the circuit court.Â  Dean, 313 S.C. at 259-60, 437 S.E.2d at 155.Â  Pursuant to this rule, the
  standard of review in equity cases in which the circuit court concurs with the
  probate court is whether there is any evidence which reasonably supports the
  findings of the court below.Â  Id. at 260, 437 S.E.2d at 155-56.
The
  specific choice of who should serve as guardian and conservator is decided
  under the probate courtâ€™s discretion.Â  â€œThe matter of a selection of a guardian
  is within the discretion of the court, and the appellate court ordinarily will
  not interfere unless a clear abuse of discretion is shown.â€Â  39 C.J.S. Guardian
    and Ward Â§ 28 (2003).Â  â€œSubject to statutory
  restrictions, the selection of a guardian is a matter committed largely to the
  discretion of the appointing court, whose decision will only be interfered with
  on appeal in the case of a clear abuse of discretion.â€Â  39 Am. Jur. 2d Guardian
    and Ward Â§ 40 (1999).Â  
The
  relevant statutes in this case, sections 62-5-311 and 62-5-410 of the South
  Carolina Code, indicate the appointing court has discretion by using the
  phrases â€œmay be appointed guardianâ€ and â€œthe court may appoint . . . as
  conservator,â€ respectively.Â  The appointing court will not be overturned absent an
  abuse of discretion. Â See Patterson v. Cook, 288
  S.C. 220, 221, 341 S.E.2d 782, 782 (1986) (interpreting an appointment statute
  without priority guidelines).Â  
DISCUSSION
Daughter argues the
  probate court, and in turn the circuit court, erred by failing to make a
  finding of good cause when appointing third parties as Motherâ€™s guardian and
  conservator because Daughter had statutory priority as Motherâ€™s attorney-in-fact.Â 
  We agree.
Section 62-5-311 of
  the South Carolina Code provides the order of priority for guardian appointees,
  stating:

  (A) Any competent
    person or a suitable institution may be appointed guardian of an incapacitated
    person.
        
    (B) Subject to a finding of good cause by the court, persons who are not
    disqualified have priority for appointment as guardian in the following order:
  . . .
  (2) an attorney in fact appointed by the incapacitated person
    pursuant to Section 62-5-501,
    whose authority includes powers relating to the person of the incapacitated
    person;

S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 62-5-311 (Supp. 2006)(emphasis added). 
Section
  62-5-410 of the South Carolina Code provides the order of priority for
  conservator appointees, stating:

  (a) The court may
    appoint an individual, or a corporation with general power to serve as trustee,
    as conservator of the estate of a protected person. The following are entitled
    to consideration for appointment in the order listed:
  . . . 
  (3) an attorney in fact appointed by such protected person
    pursuant to Â§ 62- 5-501;
  . . . 
  
    (b) . . . Â The court, for good cause, may pass over a person having priority
      and appoint a person having less priority or no priority.

S.C. Code Ann. 62-5-410 (1987 & Supp. 2006)(emphasis added).
Good
  cause is defined as â€œ[a] legally sufficient reason.Â  Good cause is often the
  burden placed on the litigant . . . to show why a request should be granted or
  excused.â€Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 235 (8th ed. 2004).Â  
Based on the language of the applicable statutes, we believe
  before a probate court bypasses a person with a statutory priority for the
  appointment of a conservator or guardian, it must make a finding of good cause
  by articulating its reasons for such a finding.Â Â  See Hodges v.
    Rainey, 341 S.C. 79, 85, 533 S.E.2d 578, 581 (2000) (If a statuteâ€™s language is plain, unambiguous, and conveys a clear
  meaning, then â€œthe rules of statutory interpretation are not needed and the
  court has no right to impose another meaning.â€); McClanahan v. Richland
    County Council, 350 S.C. 433, 438, 567 S.E.2d 240, 242 (2002)(â€œAll rules of
  statutory construction are subservient to the one that legislative intent must
  prevail if it can be reasonably discovered in the language used.â€); cf. Aycock
    v. Aycock, 284 S.C. 193, 195, 324 S.E.2d 650, 651 (Ct. App. 1984)
  (reversing award of unallocated alimony and support to wife, who had custody of
  children, where family courtâ€™s order gave no cause or reason for award where
  applicable statute required that â€œif an award of unallocated alimony and
  support payments is to be made, there must first be a finding of fact that
  there is good cause to make this award rather than allocated awardsâ€). 
In the instant case, the probate court passed over Daughterâ€™s
  statutory priority without a specific finding of good cause in the orders
  appointing a third-party guardian and a third-party conservator.Â  In its
  orders, the probate court acknowledged that Mother had executed a durable power
  of attorney in favor of Daughter.Â  Without explanation the court cancelled
  Daughterâ€™s power of attorney and found that it was â€œnecessary and desirableâ€ to
  appoint a third-party guardian and conservator. 
From all indications in the record, Daughter had taken good care
  of Mother.Â  Although the probate court indicated in its order that Mother
  wanted a third party appointed because of the friction between her children, the
  evidence includes testimony of Dr. Hardesty that any suggestions by Mother
  regarding who should serve as her guardian and conservator should be given limited
  weight if any. Â Admittedly, the record does include testimony of friction
  between the siblings; however, the probate courtâ€™s mere acknowledgment of the
  familyâ€™s divisiveness does not qualify as a finding of good cause.[1]Â  
As pointed out in the circuit courtâ€™s order, the probate
  court was undoubtedly cognizant of the statutory priorities.Â  The probate
  court, nevertheless, did not comply with the requirements of the statutes in
  bypassing Daughter without articulating its reasons why a third party would
  better serve as a guardian and conservator.Â  Because the probate court failed
  to make the requisite finding of good cause, we remand this case to the probate
  court for a finding consistent with sections 62-5-311 and 62-5-410.Â  See Act No. 483, 1990 S.C. Acts 2152 (amending section 62-5-311 to require a
  finding of good cause and stating â€œrelating to guardians, so as to provide for
  additional persons who may be appointed as guardian subject to a finding of
  good cause instead of the courtâ€™s discretionâ€); 21 S.C. Jur. Guardian and
    Conservator Â§ 15 (1993 & Supp. 2006) (â€œAbsent a contrary finding of
  good cause by the court, competent persons qualified to serve as guardians must
  be selectedâ€ pursuant to the prioritized list of qualified persons under
  sections 62-5-311 and 62-5-410.). Â On remand, the probate court should make specific
  findings based on the current record and should not consider additional
  testimony or evidence.
Accordingly,
  the decision of the circuit court is 
REVERSED
  AND REMANDED.[2]
HUFF,
  BEATTY, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.
  

[1]Â Â  At oral argument, the parties urged this court to
  definitively rule on whether friction or dissension between family members is
  sufficient to constitute good cause to bypass a person with a statutory priority.Â 
  In light of the probate courtâ€™s failure to make a specific finding regarding
  good cause, we do not believe this case presents the appropriate factual
  circumstances for this court to make that determination.Â  Therefore, we decline
  to rule on that issue.
[2]Â Â  In reaching our decision, we have considered the
  case law from other jurisdictions that was submitted by the parties.Â  We,
  however, conclude that the statutes and appellate decisions from this state
  provide a sufficient basis for our decision.
